{{NHLTeamSeason |League=NHL |Season=1993–94 |year=1993 |Team=Calgary Flames |Conference=[[Western Conference (NHL)|Western]] |ConferenceRank=2nd |Division=[[Pacific Division (NHL)|Pacific]] |DivisionRank=1st |Record=42–29–13 |HomeRecord=25–12–5 |RoadRecord=17–17–8 |GoalsFor=302 (3rd) |GoalsAgainst=256 (11th) |GeneralManager=[[Doug Risebrough]] |Coach=[[Dave King (ice hockey)|Dave King]] |Captain=[[Joe Nieuwendyk]] |AltCaptain=[[Al MacInnis]]
[[Joel Otto]] |Arena=[[Olympic Saddledome]] |Attendance=19,325 |GoalsLeader=[[Gary Roberts (ice hockey)|Gary Roberts]] (41) |AssistsLeader=[[Al MacInnis]] (54) |PointsLeader=[[Robert Reichel]] (93) |PIMLeader=[[Ron Stern]] (243) |WinsLeader=[[Mike Vernon (ice hockey)|Mike Vernon]] (26) |GAALeader=Mike Vernon (2.81) |DivisionWin=Yes }} The '''[[1993–94 NHL season|1993–94]] [[Calgary Flames]] season''' was the [[Calgary Flames seasons|14th]] [[National Hockey League]] [[Season (sports)|season]] in [[Calgary]]. It was a season of change across the NHL, as the league reorganized its divisions and playoff format. The [[Smythe Division]] was retired and the Flames joined the new [[Pacific Division (NHL)|Pacific Division]] of the [[Western Conference (NHL)|Western Conference]], as the NHL aligned itself with the other major sports leagues in naming divisions by geographical boundaries. The change angered fans, who preferred the traditional convention, which honoured the game's past builders.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/hockey/nhl/01/18/values.debate/index.html A question of values], sportsillustrated.com, January 18, 2007, accessed March 4, 2007 Realignment also led to significant changes in the playoff format, as the top eight teams in each conference now qualified for the post-season, rather than the top four in each division. Under the new format, the top team in each division was guaranteed one of the top two seeds, and declared the divisional champion, as opposed to having to win two playoff rounds to capture the division title. Thus, the Flames became the first Pacific Division champions, and the second seed in the playoffs. They faced the second place [[Vancouver Canucks]] in the playoffs rather than the fourth place [[Mighty Ducks of Anaheim]] who failed to qualify under the new system.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1272/is_n2582_v122/ai_14716426 Hockey's revised roadmap], USAToday, reproduced by findarticles.com, November 1993, accessed March 4, 2007 The playoffs ended in another bitter disappointment, as the Flames blew a 3–1 series lead, losing the last three games in overtime to the Canucks,All-time playoff results, ''2006–07 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', pg. 220 who would eventually go onto the [[Stanley Cup]] finals before bowing out to the [[New York Rangers]].[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/nhl/features/si_stanley_cup/1994/ SI Flashback: Stanley Cup 1994], sportsillustrated.com, accessed March 4, 2007 Two Flames represented the Western Conference at the [[45th National Hockey League All-Star Game|1994 All-Star Game]]: Forward [[Joe Nieuwendyk]] and defenceman [[Al MacInnis]].All-star selections, ''2006–07 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', pg. 22 For the second consecutive season, four Flames reached the 30-goal plateau. Three of them (Theoren Fleury, Robert Reichel and Gary Roberts) were also 40-goal scorers.https://www.hockey-reference.com/teams/CGY/1993.htmlhttps://www.hockey-reference.com/teams/CGY/1994.html Prior to the season, Calgary lost two players in the [[1993 NHL Expansion Draft]], as the [[Florida Panthers]] selected defenceman [[Alexander Godynyuk]] 13th overall, and centre [[Brian Skrudland]] 32nd overall. The Mighty Ducks of Anaheim did not select any Flames players. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Regular season== The Flames were shorthanded a total of 465 times during the regular season, the most among all 26 teams.{{cite web|url=https://www.hockey-reference.com/leagues/NHL_1994.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130929125153/http://www.hockey-reference.com/leagues/NHL_1994.html |archivedate=2013-09-29 |df= }} ===Season standings=== {{1993–94 NHL Pacific Division standings |team=CAL}} {{1993–94 NHL Western Conference standings|team=CAL}} ==Schedule and results== {| class="toccolours" width=90% style="clear:both; bgcolor=#E17E7E|April: 4–2–1 (Home: 3–0–0; Road: 1–2–1) |- align="center" bgcolor="#dddddd" | '''#''' || '''Date''' || '''Visitor''' || '''Score''' || '''Home''' || '''OT''' || '''Record''' || '''Pts''' |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffffbb" | 78 || April 2 || Calgary || 3 – 3 || Detroit || || 38–27–13 || 89 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 79 || April 3 || Calgary || 1 – 2 || Chicago || || 38–28–13 || 89 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 80 || April 6 || Anaheim || 2 – 4 || Calgary || || 39–28–13 || 91 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 81 || April 8 || San Jose || 2 – 5 || Calgary || || 40–28–13 || 93 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 82 || April 9 || Detroit || 2 – 4 || Calgary || || 41–28–13 || 95 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 83 || April 11 || Calgary || 3 – 0 || Anaheim || || 42–28–13 || 97 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 84 || April 13 || Calgary || 4 – 6 || Los Angeles || || 42–29–13 || 97 |} |} ==Playoffs== The Flames entered the 1994 [[Stanley Cup]] playoffs as the second seed under the new alignment, facing the seventh seeded [[Vancouver Canucks]]. After getting blown out at home in game one, the Flames responded by winning the next three games to take a 3–1 series lead. The Flames, however, lost the last three games in overtime, as they proved unable to overcome a series of injuries to key players, and the tenacious play of the Canucks. [[Pavel Bure]] scored the series winner on a breakaway in double overtime for the Canucks, who reached the Stanley Cup finals before falling to the [[New York Rangers]] in seven games. For the Flames, it was another year of playoff frustration, as for the fifth consecutive year, Calgary failed to reach the second round of the post-season. {| class="toccolours" width=90% style="clear:both; margin:1.5em auto; text-align:center;" |- ! colspan=11 style="background:#FFC859" | [[1994 Stanley Cup playoffs]] |- | colspan=11 | {| class="toccolours collapsible collapsed" width=100% align="center" |- ! colspan=11; bgcolor=#E17E7E|Western Conference quarter-final vs. Vancouver (7) |- align="center" bgcolor="#dddddd" | '''Game''' || '''Date''' || '''Visitor''' || '''Score''' || '''Home''' || '''OT''' || '''Attendance''' || '''Series''' |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 1 || April 18 || Vancouver || 5 – 0 || Calgary || || 17,764 || Vancouver leads 1–0 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 2 || April 20 || Vancouver || 5 – 7 || Calgary || || 18,318 || Series tied 1–1 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 3 || April 22 || Calgary || 4 – 2 || Vancouver || || 16,150 || Calgary leads 2–1 |- align="center" bgcolor="#bbffbb" | 4 || April 24 || Calgary || 3 – 2 || Vancouver || || 16,150 || Calgary leads 3–1 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 5 || April 26 || Vancouver || 2 – 1 || Calgary || OT || 19,059 || Calgary leads 3–2 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 6 || April 28 || Calgary || 2 – 3 || Vancouver || OT || 16,150 || Series tied 3–3 |- align="center" bgcolor="#ffbbbb" | 7 || April 30 || Vancouver || 4 – 3 || Calgary || 2OT || 20,230 || Vancouver wins 4–3 |} |} ==Player statistics== ===Skaters=== ''Note: GP = Games played; G = Goals; A = Assists; Pts = Points; PIM = Penalty minutes'' {| BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="3" CELLSPACING="2" ID="Table1" |- ALIGN="center" bgcolor="#c0c0c0" ! Murphy]]||{{flagu|Canada}}||RW||[[St. Lawrence University]] (NCAA)|| || || || || |} ==Farm teams== ===[[Saint John Flames]]=== The [[1993–94 AHL season|1993–94]] [[American Hockey League]] season was the first for the Flames top minor league affiliate as the new expansion team was created in [[Saint John, New Brunswick]]. The Flames posted a respectable 37–33–10 record in their first season, good enough for second in the Atlantic division. They fell to the [[Moncton Hawks]] in seven games in the first round of the playoffs, however.[http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/playoffdisplay.php3?league=AHL1941&season=1994&leaguenm=AHL 1993–94 AHL playoffs], hockeydb.com, accessed March 4, 2007 [[Cory Stillman]] led the Flames with 35 goals, while [[Mark Freer]] lead with 86 points. [[Jason Muzzatti]] was the starting goaltender, posting a 26–23–3 record with a 3.74 GAA in 51 games.[http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/teams/0002601994.html Saint John Flames player stats], hockeydb.com, accessed March 4, 2007 ==See also== *[[1993–94 NHL season]] ==References== {{refbegin}} *'''Player stats:''' ''2006–07 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', pg 118 *'''Game log:''' ''2006–07 Calgary Flames Media Guide'', pg 137 *'''Team standings:''' [http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/nhl19271994.html 1993–94 NHL standings] @hockeydb.com *'''Trades''': [http://www.hockeydb.com hockeydb.com] player pages {{refend}} {{reflist}} {{Calgary Flames seasons}} {{Calgary Flames}} {{1993–94 NHL season by team}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1993-94 Calgary Flames season}} [[Category:Calgary Flames seasons]] [[Category:1993–94 in Canadian ice hockey by team|C]] [[Category:1993–94 NHL season by team|C]]

Odeum Colorado (2009–10) | location = 11450 Broomfield Ln
[[Broomfield, Colorado|Broomfield, CO]] 80021-7904 | coordinates = | broke_ground = {{Start date|2005|10|18}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|2006|11|09}} | renovated = 2009–10 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Broomfield Urban Renewal Authority | operator = Peak Entertainment | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = US$45 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|45000000|2005}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Sink Combs Dethlefs | project_manager = International Coliseums Company | structural engineer = Martin & Martin Consulting Engineers | services engineer = ME Engineers | general_contractor = Sanders Construction, Inc | main_contractors = | capacity = 7,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Rocky Mountain Rage]] ([[Central Hockey League|CHL]]) (2006–09)
[[Colorado 14ers]] ([[NBA D-League]]) (2006–09)
[[Denver Roller Dolls]] ([[Women's Flat Track Derby Association|WFTDA]]) (2010–present) | embedded = | website = {{URL|http://www.1stbankcenter.com/|Venue Website}} | publictransit = }} The '''1stBank Center''' (originally the '''Broomfield Event Center''' and formerly the '''Odeum Colorado''') is a multi-purpose arena located 15 miles northwest of [[Downtown Denver]], in the city of [[Broomfield, Colorado|Broomfield]]. It is located near the [[Rocky Mountain Metropolitan Airport]] and the [[Flatiron Crossing Mall]]. Opening in 2006, the arena naming rights belong to 1stBank, a local financial institution since 2010. The venue is typically used for mid-sized concerts in the [[Denver-Aurora-Lakewood, CO Metropolitan Statistical Area|Denver Metro]] area, seating up to 7,500 patrons. From June 2010 until May 2014, the arena housed the Colorado Music Hall of Fame before it moved to its permanent home at the [[Red Rocks Amphitheatre]].{{cite web |url=http://denver.cbslocal.com/2013/11/10/colorado-music-hall-of-fame-to-permanently-move-to-red-rocks/ |title=Colorado Music Hall of Fame To Permanently Move To Red Rocks | date=November 10, 2013 |website=[[KCNC-TV]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} For sports, it is the current home of the [[Denver Roller Dolls]]{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Paula |date=January 21, 2010 |title=Roller derby coming to Broomfield's Odeum|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2010/01/18/daily72.html?page=all |newspaper=Denver Business Journal |accessdate=January 28, 2014 }} and former home of the [[Rocky Mountain Rage]] and [[Colorado 14ers]].{{cite news | title=Broomfield Event Center opens Thursday |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2006/11/06/daily32.html |newspaper=Denver Business Journal |date=November 7, 2006|accessdate=January 28, 2014 }} ==History== [[File:Broomfield Event Center.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Exterior of arena during construction, May 2009]] The City and County of Broomfield unveiled plans for a new sports facility in the Denver Metro area, in May 2005. Led by Jim Wiens and John Few, the venue is an anchor for the 215-acre commercial and residential development, Arista Metropolitan District (also called Arista Broomfield). The facility would serve as competition for several mid-sized venues in Colorado, including the: [[Magness Arena]], [[Bellco Theatre]], [[Fillmore Auditorium (Denver)|Fillmore Auditorium]], [[Budweiser Events Center]], [[World Arena, Colorado Springs|World Arena]] and the (now defunct) City Lights Pavilion.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.westword.com/backbeat/2009/12/odeum_colorado_--_the_new_name.php |title=Odeum Colorado -- the new name for the Broomfield Event Center -- to open this spring with pair of concerts by Furthur |last1=Herrera |first1=Dave |last2= |first2= |date=December 3, 2009 |website=[[Westword]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} To set it apart from its competition, the arena was designed to give an arena-sized show a theatre (intimate) feeling. Construction began in October 2006 to a rocky start. Six months after construction began, the venue's owners faced a lawsuit regarding noise control. Before opening, the facility saw several staff and management changes. Despite pushbacks, the venue opened on November 9, 2006, with a concert by [[Bonnie Raitt]]. However, the facility proved it couldn’t stand against its competitors. Many patrons complained of lack of parking and street sign leading to the venue. Others complained about the acoustics, describing the arena as a concrete barn. For its first two years of operation, the venue did not see a profit. It was unable to pay bills and staff salaries.{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Paula |date= |title=Broomfield Event Center weathers growing pains |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2007/03/26/story5.html?page=all |newspaper=Denver Business Journal |accessdate=January 28, 2014 }} Until 2009, the arena was operated by Broomfield Sports and Entertainment (created by Wiens and Frew).{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Paula |date=February 4, 2010 |title=FirstBank buys naming rights to Broomfield arena |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2010/02/01/daily55.html?page=all |newspaper=[[Denver Business Journal]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} Management ceased when the company could no longer financially afford to maintain the failing venue.{{cite news |last=Moore |first=Paula |date=February 18, 2009 |title=Broomfield seeks new operator for Events Center |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2009/02/16/daily39.html?page=all |newspaper=Denver Business Journal |accessdate=January 28, 2014 }} The Broomfield Urban Renewal Authority (BURA) began seeking a new management company in January 2009. [[AEG Live]], VenuWorks and [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] all placed bids.{{cite news | title=Report: Anschutz's AEG, SMG vying for Broomfield Event Center contract |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2009/04/27/daily25.html?page=all|newspaper=Denver Business Journal |date=April 27, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2014 }} Operations were passed off to Peak Entertainment—a joint venture between [[Kroenke Sports Enterprises]] and AEG Live Rocky Mountains, in June 2009, for 28 years.{{cite news | title=Anschutz-Kroenke venture picked to run Broomfield Event Center |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2009/06/15/daily50.html?page=all|newspaper=Denver Business Journal |date=June 17, 2009 |accessdate=January 28, 2014 }} Chuck Morris, President and CEO or AEG Live Rocky Mountains, was responsible to the revitalization of the Fillmore Auditorium. Under the new management, the venue saw over one million dollars in renovations.{{cite web |url=http://www.broomfieldenterprise.com/ci_13909884 |title=Odeum new name in Broomfield entertainment |last1=Davidson |first1=Michael |last2= |first2= |date=December 2, 2009 |website=[[Broomfield Enterprise]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} This included a new paint job, window treatments, terrace balconies, improvements to lighting and acoustics. Over 2,000 parking spaces were added, along with a pedestrian bridge connecting patrons to RTD's US 36 and Broomfield Park-n-Ride.{{cite web |url=http://blogs.westword.com/backbeat/2010/03/a_first_look_at_the_newly_reno.php |title=Moving Pictures: A first look at the newly renovated 1st Bank Center |last1=Herrera |first1=Dave|last2= |first2= |date=March 4, 2010 |website=Westword |accessdate=January 28, 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dailycamera.com/ci_14436498?source=most_viewed |title=Broomfield 1stBank Center off to fast start |last1=Collins |first1=Mark |last2= |first2= |date=February 22, 2010 |website=[[Daily Camera]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} During this construction period, the facility was given a temporary name change of Odeum Colorado. In February 2010, it was announced local financial institution, FirstBank Holding Company of Colorado, Inc. (known simply as 1stBank) purchased naming rights for five years, at an undisclosed amount.{{cite web |url=http://www.coloradodaily.com/out-there/ci_14328631 |title=1stBank Center: Odeum Colorado, formerly Broomfield Event Center, renamed again |last1=Davidson |first1=Michael |date=February 4, 2010 |website=[[Colorado Daily]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} The agreement began on March 1, 2010. The arena reopened on March 5, 2010, with a concert by [[Furthur (band)|Furthur]].{{cite web |url=http://www.denverpost.com/entertainment/ci_13922613 |title=With Furthur ado, Odeum Colorado to replace Broomfield Event Center |last1=Baca |first1=Ricardo |last2= |first2= |date=December 4, 2009 |website=[[The Denver Post]] |accessdate=January 28, 2014}} Since its reopening, the arena has hosted numerous concerts by popular artists, alongside family shows and sporting events. ==Naming== *Broomfield Event Center (November 9, 2006—December 8, 2009) *Odeum Colorado (December 9, 2009—February 28, 2010) (no events were held during the time as the arena was being renovated) *1stBank Center (March 1, 2010—present) ==Performers== {{Div col|colwidth=18em}} *[[Adventure Club]] *[[Arcade Fire]] *Basscrooks *[[Bear Grillz]] *[[Borgore]] *[[Carrie Underwood]] *[[Dave Matthews]] *[[Dia Frampton]] *[[Dropkick Murphy’s]] *[[Excision (musician)|Excision]] *[[Fall Out Boy]] *[[Figure (musician)|Figure]] *[[Flosstradamus]] *[[G-Eazy]] *[[Hall & Oates]] *[[Jean Michel Jarre]] *[[Judas Priest]] *Just A Gent *[[Justin Bieber]] *[[Katy Perry]] *[[Kesha|Ke$ha]] *[[Korn]] *[[Krewella]] *[[Lady Gaga]] *LAXX *[[LCD Soundsystem]] *[[Lindsey Stirling]] *[[Little Big Town]] *[[Mark Knopfler]] *[[Modest Mouse]] *[[Nero (band)]] *[[New Kids on the Block]] *[[Nine Inch Nails]] *[[Panic! [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile|FIA]] [[Formula E]] }} The '''Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez''' is a {{convert|4.304|km|mi|abbr=on}} [[motorsport]] [[race track]] in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]], named after the racing drivers [[Ricardo Rodríguez (racing driver)|Ricardo]] and [[Pedro Rodríguez (racing driver)|Pedro Rodríguez]]. The circuit got its name shortly after it opened when [[Ricardo Rodríguez (Formula One)|Ricardo Rodríguez]] died in practice for the non-Championship [[1962 Mexican Grand Prix]]. Ricardo's brother [[Pedro Rodríguez (racing driver)|Pedro]] also lost his life behind the wheel nine years later. Since [[2015 Mexican Grand Prix|2015]] the track once again is a host of the [[Formula One]] [[Mexican Grand Prix]], an event it previously hosted in two separarate time periods on a different layout, the last occasion of which was in [[1992 Mexican Grand Prix|1992]]. The circuit is located within the public park of the [[Magdalena Mixhuca Sports City]] in southeast [[Mexico City]]. The circuit is owned by the Government of the City, but is currently operated under concession by Corporación Interamericana de Entretenimiento (CIE) through OCESA, one of CIE's subsidiaries. CIE also organizes the [[NASCAR]] and Desafío Coron races in this circuit and rents the circuits to other parties, including race organizers, automobile clubs and track amateurs for fees that are controversial due to their disproportionately high amounts compared to other ex-F1 courses. The [[NASCAR]] [[Xfinity Series]] started racing at Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez in the 2005 season and ended in the 2008 season. [[Martin Truex Jr.]] won the race in 2005, and [[Denny Hamlin]] won in 2006. For the 2007 race, the chicane was removed to increase passing opportunities down the front straight and into turn 1, and [[Juan Pablo Montoya]] from [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]], won the race. [[Kyle Busch]] was the winner of the race in 2008. The [[A1 Grand Prix]] series started racing at Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez in the [[2006–07 A1 Grand Prix season|2006–07 season]] using the full-track configuration used by [[Formula One]]. [[Alex Yoong]] from [[A1 Team Malaysia|Malaysia]] won the sprint race and [[Oliver Jarvis]] from the [[United Kingdom]] won the feature race. In the [[2007–08 A1 Grand Prix season|2007–08 season]], [[Jonny Reid]] from [[A1 Team New Zealand|New Zealand]] won the sprint race and [[Adam Carroll]] of [[A1 Team Ireland|Team Ireland]] won the feature race. ==History== Built in a public park in 1959, the circuit hosted its first [[Formula One]] [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]] in 1962, as a non-Championship race. The following year the [[Mexican Grand Prix]] became a full World Championship event. The circuit remained part of the F1 calendar through 1970, when spectator overcrowding caused unsafe conditions. When the track re-opened in 1986, the circuit boasted a new pit complex, as well as improved safety all around. In 2001 CIE and Forsythe Racing tasked D3 Motorsport Development with revamping the circuit. A redesign to include the Foro and a complete upgrade of the circuit was done. It saw a record crowd of 402,413 people attend a round of the CART Championship in 2002. As of 2018, the Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez has been the only venue for the F1 Mexican Grand Prix. It was announced in May 2012, that the circuit would again host the [[Mexican Grand Prix]] from 2013, in a five-year deal that would see it replace the [[European Grand Prix]] in [[Valencia Street Circuit|Valencia]],{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/2012/05/29/motor/formula1/1338288393.html |title=México tendrá gran premio ya para 2013 |publisher=MARCA.com |date= |accessdate=30 May 2012}} but this did not happen. The FIA listed the Mexican Grand Prix as the 19th round of the provisional schedule for the [[2014 Formula One season|2014 season]],{{cite web|url=http://www.f1fanatic.co.uk/2013/09/05/mexico-in-new-jersey-out-on-21-race-2014-calendar/ |title=2014 Calendar draft has 21 races including Mexico |publisher=f1fanatic.co.uk |date= |accessdate=5 September 2013}} but it was not on the finalized schedule. The Mexican Grand Prix was listed on the 2015 Formula One calendar published by the FIA on 3 December 2014, with [[Formula One]] making its return to the circuit with the race on 1 November 2015.{{cite web|title=World Motor Sport Council 2014 - Doha |url=http://www.fia.com/node/9172 |publisher=FIA |accessdate=22 December 2014 |date=3 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150319200239/http://www.fia.com/node/9172 |archivedate=19 March 2015 |df=dmy }} The racetrack is also home to Insomnniacs Electric Daisy Carnival (EDC Mexico) a popular music festival and experience attended by over 200,000 people.{{cite web|url=https://mexico.electricdaisycarnival.com/en/travel/#location|title=TRAVEL - EDC Mexico 2018|website=electricdaisycarnival.com|accessdate=13 February 2018}} == The Grand Prix circuit == [[File:Grand-Am Rolex Series Mexico 2008.jpg|thumb|left|355px|[[Grand-Am Rolex Series]] taking a bypass from turn 4 to turn 8]] The circuit has an elevation of 2,285 m (7,500 ft); the thin air causes difficulties for both the drivers and their cars. The circuit has an extremely fast final corner (the ''Peraltada'', turn 17) before a long start/finish straight, and thus reminded some of [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza|Monza]]; however, unlike Monza's ''parabolica'' curve, the ''Peraltada'' curve is slightly banked, allowing even more speed through the corner. It was at this corner that the younger Rodríguez crashed, due to suspension failure. After the last F1 Mexican Grand Prix in 1992, a baseball stadium called the ''"Foro"'' was built on the inner part of this curve. When the [[Champ Car]] series began using the track in 2002, the ''Peraltada'' curve was partially bypassed by a series of sharp turns entering and exiting the ''Foro''; re-entering the ''Peraltada'' halfway through. After the Peraltada comes the long 1.2 km front straight. During the original turbo era in Formula One the faster cars were regularly clocking speeds of up to {{Convert|330|kph|mph|0|abbr=on}} on the straight. In the [[2005 NASCAR Busch Series]] season, there was a [[chicane]] on the main straightaway to slow the cars down. They also introduced a curve between the short course and the Ese del Lago to bypass the latter, but avoiding the stadium detour. The Grand Prix circuit underwent a significant renovation under the direction of [[Hermann Tilke]] for the return of [[Formula One]] in {{F1|2015}}. The front straight was slightly extended and reprofiled to accommodate a new media center and paddock. The iconic esses between turns 7 and 13 were significantly modified; the prolific, high radius turns largely diminished and some replaced with fixed angle turns. The baseball field portion of the track was also altered to a low speed left-right combination that bypassed the first half of the Peraltada, allowing the cars to re-enter the Peraltada halfway through the corner. At {{convert|4.304|km|mi}}, the course is {{convert|170|m|ft}} shorter than the previous Grand Prix layout, and [[Mexican Grand Prix]] organisers predicted lap times of around 75 seconds and speeds in excess of {{convert|328|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} for the [[Formula one engines#2014|current turbocharged Formula One cars]], which eliminate the adverse effects of altitude present in naturally aspirated cars. However it turns out the modern V6 hybrid turbo F1 cars managed to reach the top speed in excess of {{convert|370|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} down the main straight. {{clear|left}} == The oval track == [[File:Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez 1986-2014.svg|thumb|right|250px|The 1986–2001 Grand Prix layout.]] [[File:Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez 1963.svg|thumb|right|250px|The original Magdalena Mixhuca circuit used in 1962–1970.]] [[File:Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez formula-e.svg|thumb|right|250px|The Formula E layout, based on both the oval and modern Grand Prix layouts]] The circuit also features an oval layout due to the inclusion of a flat turn that goes from the middle of the main straight to the beginning of the back stretch of circuit. Unlike the road course, the oval is raced in counter-clockwise direction (except for the Formula E race). The oval configuration of this Mexico City facility is arguably the most dangerous racetrack in Mexico, because of the limited visibility at the exit of Turns 2 and 4. This is because the [[Foro Sol]] baseball stadium is located inside turns 1 and 2; and several trees are located inside turns 3 and 4. During the 2006 season, two accidents occurred in the oval track during [[NASCAR Mexico T4 Series]] events, which took several drivers out of the race and even required some of them to be taken to hospital. The oval configuration is used at least twice a year, with two double-feature events featuring the [[NASCAR Toyota Series]] and the [[NASCAR Mexico T4 Series]]. The oval configuration also forms the base of the [[FIA Formula E Championship]] circuit for the [[Mexico City ePrix]]; the oval is raced clockwise, but there is a chicane that will be used prior to the entrance of Turn 4, with a second chicane on the backstretch, followed by a modified [[Foro Sol]] section that exits for the full Peraltada, and a third chicane will be placed midway through the Peraltada (Turns 1 and 2 of the oval). FIA Formula E track design was modified by Agustin Delicado Zomeño. == Renamed turns == In 2015 the Turn 17 of the Autodromo Hermanos Rodríguez was baptized in honour of [[Formula One]] legend [[Nigel Mansell]], twice winner of the Mexican Grand Prix of [[1987 Mexican Grand Prix|1987]] and [[1992 Mexican Grand Prix|1992]].{{cite web|url=https://www.formula1.com/en/latest/headlines/2015/9/mexico-names-final-corner-after-nigel-mansell.html|title=Mexico names final corner after Nigel Mansell|website=formula1.com|accessdate=13 February 2018}} On September 20, 2016 [[Adrián Fernández]]'s achievements have been recognised by the naming of Turn 12 of the Autodromo in his honour.{{cite web|url=http://www.motorsport.com/f1/news/adrian-fernandez-has-corner-named-after-him-in-mexico-city-829213/|title=Adrian Fernandez has corner named after him in Mexico City|website=motorsport.com|accessdate=13 February 2018}} == Current races == * [[Copa Turismo México]] – [[Copa Turismo México Presentada por Continental y FIAT]] * [[Moto Pro México]] – [[Copa Turismo México Presentada por Continental y FIAT]] * [[Formula One]] – [[Mexican Grand Prix]] * [[Formula E]] – [[Mexico City ePrix]] * [[FIA World Endurance Championship]] - [[6 Hours of Mexico]] == The baseball stadium == {{Main|Foro Sol}} The Autódromo is unique in the sense that there is a baseball stadium inside Turn 14 (Peraltada). The stadium, called [[Foro Sol]], was home to the [[Diablos Rojos del México]], and also hosts music concerts. Artists like [[Iron Maiden]], [[Paul McCartney]], [[Metallica]], [[Pink Floyd]], [[Santana (band)|Santana]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Stone Temple Pilots]], [[Nine Inch Nails]], [[U2]], and [[Radiohead]] are just a few of the names that have played there. The Coca-Cola Zero Festival was held at the racetrack on 12 April 2008 [http://coca-colazero.com.mx/]. Acts included [[The Smashing Pumpkins]], [[The Mars Volta]], [[My Chemical Romance]], [[My Morning Jacket]], [[Belanova]], [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]], [[Kinky (band)|Kinky]] and [[Miranda!]]. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.autodromohermanosrodriguez.com/}} * [http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/cir-043.html Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez Page] at GrandPrix.com (focusing on [[Formula One]] history) *[https://www.google.com/maps/place/Aut%C3%B3dromo+Hermanos+Rodriguez,+Granjas+M%C3%A9xico,+08400+Ciudad+de+M%C3%A9xico,+D.F.,+Mexico/@19.4034591,-99.0909719,17z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x85d1fc2157a79377:0x33ff6581b240a2dd!8m2!3d19.4034591!4d-99.0887832 Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez] on Google Maps {{Navboxes |list = {{Formula One circuits}} {{FIA WEC circuits}} {{Formula E circuits}} {{World Sportscar Championship circuits}} {{Champ Car tracks}} {{IMSA GT circuits}} {{Grand-Am circuits}} {{A1 Grand Prix circuits}} {{NASCAR Nationwide Series racetracks}} {{NASCAR Corona Series racetracks}} {{LATAM Challenge Series racetracks}} {{Mexico motor racing circuits}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Autodromo Hermanos Rodriguez}} [[Category:Sports venues in Mexico City]] [[Category:Motorsport venues in Mexico|Hermanos]] [[Category:Mexican Grand Prix]] [[Category:Mexico City ePrix]] [[Category:Champ Car circuits]] [[Category:Formula One circuits|Hermanos]] [[Category:NASCAR tracks|Hermanos]] [[Category:A1 Grand Prix circuits]] [[Category:IMSA GT Championship circuits]] [[Category:Formula E circuits]] [[Category:1962 establishments in Mexico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1962]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = BT Arena | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image =Cluj_Polyvalent_Hall_2.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = Interior | fullname = | location = [[Cluj-Napoca]], Romania | coordinates = {{Coord|46|46|1.1|N|23|34|13.4|E|region:RO_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | opened = 21 October 2014 | renovated = 2017 | expanded = 2017 | owner = | operator = Cluj-Napoca City Council | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = [[Euro|€]]16.5 million (2014) | architect = [[Dico si Tiganas|Dico și Țigănaș]] | project_manager = | structural engineer = Plan 31 | services engineer = | general_contractor = SC CON-A SA | main_contractors = Nisal
Intersport | capacity = 9,300 (tennis, basketball)
10,000 (concerts, kickboxing, MMA)[https://cluj.com/articole/10-000-de-locuri-la-sala-polivalenta-2017/ 10 000 de locuri la Sala Polivalentă în 2017 {{ro icon}}.] | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[U BT Cluj-Napoca|U-BT Cluj-Napoca]] ([[Divizia A (Baschet Masculin)|Divizia A]])
[[Universitatea Cluj-Napoca (women's handball)|Universitatea Cluj-Napoca]] ([[Liga Naţională (Handbal Feminin)|Liga Naţională]]) | website = [http://polivalentacluj.ro/ polivalentacluj.ro] }} The '''BT Arena''' is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] that is located in [[Cluj-Napoca]], Romania. The arena was previously called the '''Polyvalent Hall''' but was renamed on 17 October 2017 when the facility entered into a new arena-naming rights agreement with [[Banca Transilvania]].{{cite web|url=http://www.totalbaschet.ro/articol/Sala-Polivalent%C4%83-din-Cluj-Napoca-devine-BT-Arena~53879|title=Banca Transilvania a semnat n contract pe cinci ani cu arena clujeană|publisher=Total Baschet|date=18 October 2017|language=Romanian}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telekomsport.ro/a-inceput-amenajarea-suprafetei-de-zgura-la-bt-arena-din-cluj-napoca-pentru-intalnirea-romania-elvetia-din-fedcup-18064764|title=A început amenajarea suprafeţei de zgură la BT Arena din Cluj-Napoca, pentru întâlnirea România – Elveţia, din FedCup|publisher=Telekom Sport|accessdate=9 May 2018|language=Romanian}} The venue holds 10,000 people in its largest configuration. The building is located next to the [[Cluj Arena]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cotidiantr.ro/noua-*bijuterie*-a-clujului-sala-polivalenta-gata-de-inaugurare-75279.php#.VC6T__l_tS1|title=Sala Polivalentă, gata de inaugurare|publisher=Cotidianul Transilvan|date=24 September 2014|language=Romanian}} ==History== The arena opened on 21 October 2014. The arena hosted a concert, on 31 October 2014, by English musician [[James Blunt]], who sang from his album [[Moon Landing (album)|Moon Landing]]. The concert had an attendance of upwards of 6,000.{{cite web|url=http://stirileprotv.ro/video/sase-mii-de-oameni-au-asistat-la-concertul-lui-james-blunt-din-cluj-artistul-a-fost-purtat-pe-brate-de-fani/61591470|title=Sase mii de oameni au asistat la concertul lui James Blunt din Cluj|publisher=[[Pro TV]]|accessdate=7 November 2014|language=Romanian}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jamesblunt.com/live,cluj-polyvalent-hall_307.htm?pg=1|title=TOUR DATES|publisher=jamesblunt.com|accessdate=7 November 2014|language=Romanian}} It hosted the ''[[Counter-Strike: Global Offensive]]'' Major [[DreamHack Open Cluj-Napoca 2015]].{{cite web|url=http://open.dreamhack.se/page/clujnapoca/|title=DreamHack Open- Cluj-Napoca|website=[[DreamHack]]|accessdate=November 17, 2015}} The arena's seating capacity for basketball games was expanded to 10,000 seats for the [[EuroBasket 2017]].[https://cluj.com/articole/10-000-de-locuri-la-sala-polivalenta-2017/ 10 000 de locuri la Sala Polivalentă în 2017 {{ro icon}}.] The renovation work on the arena's existing stands began after the [[2017 European Artistic Gymnastics Championships]].{{cite web|url=https://cluj.com/articole/10-000-de-locuri-la-sala-polivalenta-2017/|title=10 000 de locuri la Sala Polivalentă în 2017|publisher=cluj.com|accessdate=19 March 2017|language=Romanian}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://polivalentacluj.ro/ Official website] {{ro icon}} *[http://www.dicositiganas.ro/portfolio/sport-leisure/multifunctional-sports-hall.html Photos of the arena at [[Dico si Tiganas|Dico și Țigănaș]] website] {{FIBA EuroBasket 2017}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Romania]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Cluj-Napoca]] [[Category:FIBA EuroBasket 2017 venues]] [[Category:Handball venues in Romania]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Romania]] [[Category:Music venues in Romania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2014]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cluj-Napoca]]

{{for|other races with similar names|Champion Stakes (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox horseraces | class = Discontinued Stakes | horse race = Champion Stakes | image = | caption = | location = [[Monmouth Park Racetrack#Long Branch Racetrack|Long Branch Racetrack]]
[[Long Branch, New Jersey]], [[United States]] | inaugurated = 1879 | race type = [[Thoroughbred]] - [[Flat racing]] | website = | distance = {{frac|1|1|2}} miles (12 furlongs) | surface = Dirt | track = left-handed | qualification = All ages | weight = Assigned | purse = | bonuses = }} The '''Champion Stakes''' was an American [[Thoroughbred horse race]] run annually in August at the Monmouth Park Association's racetrack in [[Long Branch, New Jersey]]. Inaugurated in 1879, the Champion Stakes was open to horses of any age and was raced on dirt over a distance of one and one half miles (12 [[furlong]]s). In 1891, the races at Long Branch had to be shifted to racetracks in [[New York (state)|New York]] when government legislation attempted to inhibit [[parimutuel wagering]]. The races were split between the [[Jerome Park Racetrack]] in [[Fordham, Bronx]] and at the nearby [[Morris Park Racecourse]] at [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester Village]].https://www.nytimes.com/1891/06/29/archives/no-races-at-long-branch-stake-dates-fixed-for-morris-and-jerome.html The Monmouth Park Racing Association closed and the land sold after its operating license was revoked in 1893 and government legislation was enacted that banned parimutuel wagering.https://www.nytimes.com/1893/12/26/archives/monmouth-parks-license-revoked-action-taken-by-the-local.html In the final running of the Champion Stakes in 1892, [[Lamplighter (horse)|Lamplighter]] set a new stakes and track record. ==Records== '''Speed record:''' * 2:32.75 - [[Lamplighter (horse)|Lamplighter]] (1892) '''Most wins:''' * 2 - [[Firenze (horse)|Firenze]] (1888, 1891) '''Most wins by a [[jockey]]:''' * 4 - [[Jim McLaughlin (jockey)|Jim McLaughlin]] (1880, 1881, 1884, 1887) '''Most wins by a [[Horse trainer|trainer]]:''' * 3 - [[James G. Rowe, Sr.]] (1880, 1881, 1884) * 3 - [[Matthew Byrnes]] (1888, 1990, 1991) '''Most wins by an owner:''' * 4 - [[Dwyer Brothers Stable]] (1880, 1881, 1884, 1887) ==Winners== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="background-color:#DACAA5; width:38px" | Year

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{refimprove|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Coundon Road Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = [[Coventry]], [[England]] | broke_ground = | opened = 1921 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 2004 | demolished = 2004 | owner = [[Coventry R.F.C.]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Coventry R.F.C.]] (1921-2004)
[[Coventry Bears]] (1998-2004) | seating_capacity = 9,000 | dimensions = }} '''Coundon Road Stadium''' in [[Coventry]] was the home ground for [[Coventry R.F.C.]] from 1921 to 2004. The stadium has now been demolished. [[File:Last day at coundon kickoff.jpg|thumb|left|Manchester, in red, kick off for the last match at the ground. The Main Stand is in the background.]] The first game at the ground was against United Services, [[Portsmouth]], with [[Coventry R.F.C.]] losing 13-3. The biggest crowd at the ground was reputedly 18,000 for an England versus Wales School's International on 12 March 1939. In the modern era, just over 8,000 people attended the [[National Division One|National League One]] match between [[Coventry R.F.C.]] and [[Newcastle Falcons|Newcastle]] on 2 November 1996, which was a record for the league until 2004.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-union-harris-has-the-drop-on-tough-newcastle-1350637.html |title=Rugby Union: Harris has the drop on tough Newcastle |publisher=The Independent |date=4 November 1996}}{{cite web|url=https://thesouthstandchoir.wordpress.com/2012/08/09/falcons-in-division-two-199697/ |title=Falcons in Division Two 1996/97 |publisher=thesouthstandchoir.wordpress.com |date=9 August 2012}} The stadium had two stands; the Main (Road) Stand and the terraced Cowshed, though additional temporary structures were put in place for some representative games at the ground. The two stands only had minor alterations in their 83 years of existence. However, a clubhouse was opened in 1959, next to the Main Stand. [[File:Last day at coundon match.jpg|thumb|right|Coventry applying pressure in front of the posts during the final game. The white faced building in the background is the clubhouse, with a [[cameraman]] on the roof recording the proceedings.]] Their final game at the ground was a 34-20 victory for [[Coventry R.F.C.]] against [[Manchester R.F.C.]] on 2004-04-17, with an attendance of 2,200. Coventry R.F.C moved to the [[Butts Park Arena]] in September of that year, with the old stadium being demolished during November. The site has now been developed as a [[housing estate]] by Bryant Homes. Apartment houses on the site are named after former [[Coventry R.F.C.]] players including [[David Duckham]], Bert Godwin and Peter Jackson. {{Clear}} {{Coord|52.4142|-1.5243|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Sports venues in Coventry]] [[Category:Defunct rugby union venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1921]] {{Rugbyunion-stub}} {{England-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} '''Dr. Karni Singh Shooting Range''' is a [[shooting range]] in [[New Delhi]]. Spread over 72 acres, it is situated on [[South Delhi]] ridges in the backdrop of Adilabad Fort, near the historic [[Tughlaqabad Fort]] to its North and [[Surajkund]] Lake to its South West. It was first constructed for the [[1982 Asian Games]] in New Delhi, and later rebuild altogether for the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]]. It was named after Dr. [[Karni Singh]] who won the silver medal at the 38th [[World Shooting Championships]] at Cairo in 1962 and was the first shooter to be awarded the [[Arjuna Award]] in 1961.<ref name=cwg>[http://d2010.thecgf.com/dr_karni_singh_shooting_range Dr. Karni Singh Shooting Range] [[2010 Commonwealth Games]] website.</ref> The reconstruction work started on 25 October 2008 and the project was completed at a cost of Rs. 150 crore in 13 months. It was dedicated to the nation on 31 January 2010 by Union Minister for Youth Affairs & Sports.<ref>[http://www.sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in/index2.asp?slid=567&sublinkid=294&langid=1 Dr. Karni Singh shooting range launched by Union Sports Minister Dr.M.S.Gill] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130315134142/http://www.sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in/index2.asp?slid=567&sublinkid=294&langid=1 |date=15 March 2013 }} [[Sports Authority of India]], February 1, 2010.</ref>
==Overview== In October 2008 the structure of the range was fully demolished and was built under a project a plan costing Rs. 150 crore (U$33.8 m), it was completed in 13 months.<ref>{{cite web |title=Game For The Show |url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?264891 |date=12 April 2010 |publisher=[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]}}</ref> Spread over {{convert|72|acre|m2}}, the Range has been divided into six parts — a 10-metre range, a 25-metre range, a 50-metre range, a final range, trap and skeet range and a new armoury building which were constructed with state-of-the-art technology . The earlier separate ranges for Trap and Skeet were converted into new composite ranges for Trap and Skeet with scoring equipment.
For the 10-metre shooting range, a centrally air-conditioned indoor facility with complete power back-up was constructed with a capacity of maximum of 500 spectators. Two different grids will be providing electricity to ensure complete power back-up.
The trap and skeet range is an outdoor venue with only the seating area covered; the shooter though has shade on his head. There are 50 firing points for this range.
The rebuilding of the site was followed by massive plantation and beautification would to make the site more attractive. There are also plans for constructing a 200-seated hostel which will be a self-contained facility to help the campers.
It is regarded as one of the world's best shooting range by various [[2010 Commonwealth Games]] shooters.,<ref>[http://www.cwgdelhi2010.org/news/foreign_shooters_awe_dr_karni_singh_shooting_range Foreign shooters in awe of Dr. Karni Singh Shooting Range] [[2010 Commonwealth Games]], 9 October 2010.</ref> also near by is the [[Asola Bhatti Wildlife Sanctuary]].
== References ==
<references />
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130315134142/http://sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in/index2.asp?slid=567&sublinkid=294&langid=1 Dr. Karni Singh Shooting Range, overview] {{coord|28.499759|77.266835|display=t|type:landmark}}

{{Infobox tennis cup team | Name = Ecuador | Type = Fed | Image = Flag of Ecuador.svg | Nickname = | Captain = Manuel Balda | Coach = | ITF Rank = 40 {{increase}} 6 (16 November 2015) | ITF max = | ITF max date = | ITF min = | ITF min date = | Colors = yellow & blue | First year = [[1972 Federation Cup (tennis)|1972]] | Years played = 21 | Ties played = 83 (47–36) | WG played = 1 (1–1) | Titles = | Runners-up = | Best = World Group 2R ([[1972 Federation Cup (tennis)|1972]]) | Player wins = [[María Dolores Campana]] (28–21) | Singles wins = María Dolores Campana (20–10) | Doubles wins = [[Nuria Niemes]] (16–15) | Best doubles = María Dolores Campana /
Nuria Niemes (8–10) | Most ties = María Dolores Campana (31) | Most years = Nuria Niemes (10) }} The '''Ecuador Fed Cup team''' represents [[Ecuador]] in [[Fed Cup]] [[tennis]] competition and are governed by the [[Federación Ecuatoriana de Tenis]]. They currently compete in the Americas Zone of Group II. ==History== Ecuador competed in its first Fed Cup in [[1972 Federation Cup (tennis)|1972]]. Their best result was reaching the round of 16 in their debut year. ==See also== *[[Fed Cup]] *[[Ecuador Davis Cup team]] ==External links== *{{FedCupteamlink|code=ECU}} {{Fed Cup}} {{National sports teams of Ecuador}} [[Category:Fed Cup teams]] [[Category:Tennis in Ecuador|Fed Cup]] [[Category:National sports teams of Ecuador|Fed Cup]] {{FedCup-stub}} {{ecuador-sport-stub}}

{{for|the Headingley Stadium complex|Headingley Stadium}} {{refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox stadium | image = [[File:Leeds Rhinos v Warrington Wolves (4th May 2018) 025.jpg|240px]] | image_size = 300px | caption = | fullname = Headingley Stadium | location = St Micheals Lane, Headingley, [[Leeds]], West Yorkshire, England | coordinates ={{coord|53|48|58.87|N|1|34|55.82|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} | built = 1897{{cite web |url=http://www.wafll.com/elland-road/elland-road-stats.html |title=Elland Road – Information |accessdate=3 April 2008 |publisher=wafll.com}} | opened = 1890 | renovated = 1991, 2011, 2017-18 | expanded = 1931, 1932, 2006 | demolished = | owner = [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds Rugby]] | operator = [[Leeds Rhinos]] | surface = Grass and astro turf mix | scoreboard = Philips VideoTron | architect = | former_names = | publictransit = {{rail-interchange|gb|Rail}} {{stn|Headingley}} | tenants =
[[Leeds Rhinos]] (1890–present)
[[Yorkshire Carnegie]] (1991–present)
| seating_capacity = 21,062{{cite web|url=http://www.rlfans.com/index.php?fid=41&id=200 |title=Rlfans.Com |publisher=Rlfans.Com |date= |accessdate=7 April 2013}}{{failed verification|date=June 2018}}(13,000 during redevelopment) | record_attendance = '''All Time'''
40,175 ([[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] vs [[Bradford Northern]], 21 May 1947)
'''Super League'''
23,035 ([[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] vs [[Bradford Bulls]], 2003) | dimensions = {{convert|115|x|74|yd|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.leedsunited.com/page/RecordsDetail/0,,10273,00.html |title=Club Records |accessdate=3 April 2008 |publisher=Leeds United A.F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217100057/http://www.leedsunited.com/page/RecordsDetail/0,,10273,00.html |archivedate=17 December 2007 }} }} '''Headingley Rugby Stadium''', (known as '''Emerald Headingley Stadium''' due to sponsorship), shares the same site as [[Headingley Cricket Ground]] and is home to both [[Leeds Rhinos]] and [[Yorkshire Carnegie]] rugby teams. Headingley is also the [[List of Rugby League stadiums in England|5th largest rugby league stadium in England]]. ==History== ===1889-1980s: Construction and development=== Leeds St. Johns, who were later to become Leeds Rugby League Football Club then [[Leeds Rhinos]], moved to Headingley in 1889 and built Headingley stadium. Headingley hosted [[rugby league]]'s first ever [[Challenge Cup]] Final in 1897. In the 1930s, major developments took place on two sides of the rugby ground. The South Stand was completed in 1931, with some of the work being carried out by club players, while the old wooden North Stand was burned down during a match against Halifax on 25 March 1932. By the end of 1932, a new North Stand had been completed. The record attendance at Headingley was 40,175 for the rugby league match between Leeds and [[Bradford Northern]] on 21 May 1947. Undersoil heating was installed in 1963 but has since been removed due to ongoing problems, and [[Floodlights (sport)|floodlight]]s were installed in 1966. The [[1970 Rugby League World Cup Final]] between [[Great Britain Lions|Great Britain]] and [[Australian Kangaroos|Australia]] was played at the stadium before a crowd of 18,776. The third and deciding Test of the [[The Ashes (rugby league)|1978 Ashes series]] was played at Headingley before a crowd of 30,604. ===1990s–2000: Rugby Union and World Cup games=== New changing rooms were added in 1991, the same year [[Yorkshire Carnegie|Leeds RFU]] were founded and moved into Headingley. In July 1998, [[Leeds Carnegie|Leeds RFU]] became part of the world's first dual-code rugby partnership, Leeds Rugby Limited. Headingley only hosted one match of the [[1995 Rugby League World Cup]], held in England and Wales to celebrate the centenary of rugby league in England. Host nation [[England national rugby league team|England]] defeated rugby league minnows [[South Africa national rugby league team|South Africa]] 46–0 in front of 14,041 fans. Two matches of the [[2000 Rugby League World Cup]] were held at Headingley which included [[England national rugby league team|England]] v [[Fiji national rugby league team|Fiji]] which England won by 66–10 in front of a crowd of 10,052 and latterly the quarter final fixture between England and [[Ireland national rugby league team|Ireland]] which England won by 26–16 and attracted 15,405 spectators. ===2001–2006: East Stand Expansion and redevelopment=== In 2001 capacity was increased marginally by extending the terracing around the corner in between the Western Terraces and the North Stand. Since 2005 Headingley rugby stadium has been the venue for the annual [[Varsity match|varsity]] rugby union match between [[Leeds Beckett University]] and the [[University of Leeds]] which has attracted over 11,000 spectators.[http://www.leedsvarsity.com/ LeedsVarsity.com] retrieved 20 June 2014 2005 also saw the construction of the Carnegie Stand, built to replace the Eastern Terrace. The new stand had two tiers with 1,844 seats and hospitality suites. It was opened on 1 September 2006 for the [[Super League]] match between [[Leeds Rhinos]] and [[Warrington Wolves]]. ===2012–2015: More international games=== The [[2012 World Club Challenge]] saw the first time that the stadium was fully packed to its capacity when the home team, and [[Super League XVI]] Champions, [[Leeds Rhinos]] took on the [[2011 NRL season|2011 NRL]] winners the [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles]]. 21,062 turned out to see the Rhinos defeat Manly 26–12, the game being highlighted by [[Ryan Hall (rugby league)|Ryan Hall]]'s 90 metre intercept try midway through the first half.[http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/matches/world-club-challenge-2012/leeds-vs-manly-warringah.html 2012 World Club Challenge at Rugby League Project] This saw Leeds gain some revenge for their 28–20 loss to Manly in the [[2009 World Club Challenge]] at [[Elland Road]]. The stadium hosted two matches of the [[2013 Rugby League World Cup]]: a Group B game featuring [[New Zealand Kiwis|New Zealand]], the [[2008 Rugby League World Cup|defending World Cup Champions]], and [[Papua New Guinea Kumuls|Papua New Guinea]] on Friday 8 November which the Kiwis won 56–10 in front of an audience of 18,180. Headingley also hosted a Quarter-final game on Friday 15 November between New Zealand and [[Scotland national rugby league team|Scotland]] which New Zealand won by 40–4 to a crowd of 16,207. In 2015 Headingley hosted [[New Zealand Kiwis|New Zealand]] again for the first time since 2013 where they took on [[Leeds Rhinos]] as a warm up for their [[2015 New Zealand rugby league tour of Great Britain|test series]] against England. It also marked 120 years of rugby league being played at the stadium. ===2016–present: Major redevelopment=== In 2015 it was announced that the North and South stands were to be rebuilt as part of the redevelopment of the stadium. The new North stand will include new changing rooms and hospitality for both the cricket and rugby ground, with the cricket side having three tiers. The South Stand will also be rebuilt as it was condemned in 2011 with plans since then to rebuild the stand. The new South stand will have the same standing capacity and will also house seating due to the North stand being slightly reduced and will have a similar design as the Carnegie Stand. Work on the new South Stand began in 2017, with the old structure demolished in September of that year. The stand is due to be open for the 2019 season. ==Layout== ===Emerald North Stand=== '''Capacity- 3,825 (seated)'''
[[File:Headingley north stand construction 2018.jpg|thumb|Headingley North Stand Unser construction]] The North Stand is the main stand in the ground and backs onto the cricket stadium. The stand also houses the changing rooms as well as the media and journalists and a bankqueting suite that is shared by both the cricket and rugby grounds. ===Carnegie Stand=== [[File:Headingley Carnegie.jpg|thumb|right|Carnegie Stand]] '''Capacity- 4,550 (1,844 seated)'''
The Carnegie Stand was completed in 2006 and replaced the Eastern Terrace. The stand has two tiers; the bottom contained terracing whilst the top contains seating, hospitality boxes, bars and a restrauant. ===South Stand=== '''Capacity- 7,721 (2,217 seated)''' The South Stand is well known in rugby league for being the ''Kop'' of the ground. The stand was rebuilt in 2018 and contains two tiers, the bottom tier is terracing and the upper tier is seating. The stand also contains the TV gauntry. File:The South Stand at Headingley Stadium.jpg|The former South Stand File:Leeds Rhinos v Warrington Wolves (4th May 2018) 023.jpg|Construction of the new South Stand ===Western Terrace=== [[File:Leeds v Huddersfield Western Terrace.jpg|thumb|right|Headingley Western Terrace]] '''Capacity- 4,966 '''
The Western Terrace is the only part of the stadium not covered and houses the away fans. It is the only part of the ground that has had no major redevelopment nor are there any plans to. It also contains the scoreboard and [[Sky Sports]] video board. ===Redevelopment=== In 2015 it was announced that the North and South stands were to be rebuilt as part of the redevelopment of the stadium. The new North stand will include new changing rooms and hospitality for both the cricket and rugby ground, with the cricket side having three tiers. The South Stand will also be rebuilt as it was condemned in 2011 with plans since then to rebuild the stand. The new South stand will have the same standing capacity and will also house seating due to the North stand being slightly reduced and will have the same design as the Carnegie Stand. The only side of the ground that has not been redeveloped or are there any plans to do so is the Western Terrace due to there being a public right of way and housing behind it. The biggest change to the Western Terrace is the permanent video board in the South West corner which replaced the temporary one in the North West corner. [[File:Leeds Rhinos v Warrington Wolves (4th May 2018) 015.jpg|thumb|centre|800px|Panoramic of the ground during redevelopment.]] {{Clear}} ==Sponsors== Headingley first sold naming rights in 2006 by [[Leeds Beckett University|Leeds Metropolitan University]] during the construction of the '''Carnegie Stand'''. In 2017, Headingley sold the naming rights to Bingley-based publishers [[Emerald Group Publishing|Emerald Group]] to help fund the redevelopment of the North and South stands. {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#bdb76b ! Year!! Sponsor !! revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2007}} The '''Kids To The Country''' (KTC) is an American non-profit program that began in [[the Bronx]], [[New York (state)|New York]] by [[Plenty International]] to provide assistance to vulnerable and underprivileged children until conditions in the area improved enough to withdraw the project.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0GER/is_1999_Summer/ai_55127442 Whole Earth Article, 1999] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041124064222/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0GER/is_1999_Summer/ai_55127442 |date=2004-11-24 }}</ref> Re-established in [[Nashville]], [[Tennessee]] in 1986, KTC is a program to reduce anger, violence and fear in some of the country's most at-risk urban children. Through various nature activities, the KTC program offers urban youth the opportunity to get out of troubled situations and develop a connection to nature. Summer programs are typically five weeks<ref>[http://www.hellbenderpress.com/enter.pl?a=127 Hell Bender Press Interview]</ref> and include swimming, riding canoes and horses, crafts, hiking and studying the native landscape, gardening, star gazing, playing musical instruments, and telling stories.
A majority of the program's participants come from homeless shelters, refugee centers, and low-income neighborhoods.
Over 2,800 children have participated since Plenty International's inception of the program. The program is hosted on [[The Farm (Tennessee)|The Farm Community]] in [[Summertown, Tennessee]] on {{convert|1750|acre|km2}} of wilderness.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://plenty.org Plenty International] * [http://www.plenty.org/KTC/ Kids to the Country] * [http://thefarmcommunity.com The Farm Community]
[[Category:Children's sport]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Lakeside Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:Lakeside Stadium Logo.png]]

[[File:Lakeside Stadium - Melbourne -01.jpg|240px]] | location = Aughtie Drive, [[Albert Park, Victoria]] | coordinates = {{Coord|37|50|25|S|144|57|54|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1876 | opened = 1878 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = State Sports Centre Trust | surface = Grass (soccer stadium), blue synthetic (athletics track) | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = Lake Oval, South Melbourne Cricket Ground, Bob Jane Stadium | tenants = [[South Melbourne FC]]
[[Victorian Institute of Sport]]
[[Victorian Athletic League|Athletics Victoria]]
[[Athletics Australia]]
[[Little Athletics|Australian Little Athletics]]
[[Melbourne Victory FC Youth|Melbourne Victory FC (Youth Team)]]
[[Melbourne Victory FC (W-League)|Melbourne Victory FC (Women's Team)]]
[[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne Football Club]] (VFA/VFL, 1878–1981)
[[South Melbourne Cricket Club]] (until 1994) [[Methodist Ladies' College, Melbourne|Methodist Ladies' College]] | seating_capacity = 12,000 (7,400 seated){{cite web|url=http://www.smfc.com.au/club/lakeside-stadium/|title=Lakeside Stadium|publisher=South Melbourne FC|accessdate=5 July 2017}} | renovated = 1995, 2011 |}} '''Lakeside Stadium''' is a sports arena in [[Albert Park, Victoria|Albert Park]], [[Melbourne]], Australia. Comprising an [[athletics track]] and [[soccer]] [[stadium]], it currently serves as the home ground and administrative base for the [[South Melbourne FC]], [[Victorian Athletic League|Athletics Victoria]], [[Athletics Australia]], [[Victorian Institute of Sport]] and [[Little Athletics|Australian Little Athletics]]. The venue was built on the site of the former [[Australian rules football]] and [[cricket]] ground, '''Lake Oval''' (or '''South Melbourne Cricket Ground'''). It served for more than a century as the home ground of the [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne Football Club]] and the [[South Melbourne Cricket Club]], although it was also used for soccer from at least 1883.{{cite web|url=http://neososmos.blogspot.com.au/2013/10/victorian-soccer-fixtures-and-results_9713.html|title=Victorian Soccer Fixtures and Results 1883|work=Neos Osmos|author=Syson, Ian|date=30 September 2013|accessdate=24 June 2016}} It is one of four sporting facilities in Melbourne - the others being the [[Melbourne Sports and Aquatic Centre]] (MSAC), the MSAC Institute of Training (MIT) and the [[State Netball and Hockey Centre]] (SNHC) - to be organised under the banner of '''Melbourne Sports Hub'''. ==History== ===The Lake Oval and Australian rules football=== [[File:Old lake oval grandstand.jpg|thumb|right|250px|1926 grandstand prior to Lakeside Stadium redevelopment]] In its original oval configuration, the [[Lake Oval]] served most prominently as the home ground for [[Australian rules football]] club [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]], in both the [[Victorian Football Association]] and the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]]. In its early days, the ground was considered one of the best in the league, and was the venue for the [[1901 VFL Grand Final]]. South Melbourne used the ground for home games until the end of the [[1981 VFL season]], when the club relocated to [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]] and became the [[Sydney Swans]]. The last senior VFL match played at Lake Oval was on Saturday, 29 August 1981, when South Melbourne was defeated by 33 points against [[North Melbourne]] in front of 8484 fans. The club continued to use Lake Oval for reserves matches for several years after 1981. When electric floodlighting was installed at the venue during the 1950s, it became one of the first venues in Melbourne to regularly host night football matches, including the [[List of Australian Football League pre-season and night series premiers|night premiership series]] between 1956 and 1971. Night premiership matches in the [[Victorian Football Association]] in [[1957 VFA season|1957]] and [[1958 VFA season|1958]]{{cite news|newspaper=The Sun News-Pictorial|publication-place=Melbourne|date=2 April 1957|title=Lone V.F.A. club's 'no' to night football|page=47|author=}} and night interstate matches,{{cite news|newspaper=The Sun News-Pictorial|date=24 July 1957|title=Burst by S.A. crushes V.F.A.|page=45|publication-place=Melbourne|author=Carrick, Noel}} including many matches at the [[1958 Melbourne Carnival|1958 Interstate Carnival]]{{cite news|newspaper=The Sun News-Pictorial|date=3 July 1958|title=Big men pave way for WA|page=38|publication-place=Melbourne|author=Bretland, Bernie}} were also held at the Lake Oval. The ground record crowd for Lake Oval was set on 30 July [[1932 VFL season|1932]] when 41,000 turned out to see [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] defeat South Melbourne by nine points.{{cite web|url=http://afltables.com/afl/crowds/vn_lake_oval.html|title=Lake Oval - Attendances (1921-1981)|work=AFL Tables|accessdate=5 July 2017}}[[File:Aerial view of Albert Park Lake and the South Melbourne Cricket Ground in the foreground with a football match in progress.jpeg|thumb|Aerial photo of the South Melbourne cricket ground with a football match in progress.]] For a time during the late 1980s and early 1990s, the struggling [[Fitzroy Football Club]] used the ground as a training and administrative base.{{cite news|url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?page=1&docID=news930722_0196_0533|newspaper=The Age|publication-place=Melbourne|author=Linnell, Stephen|page=28|date=23 July 1993|title=Lion members back move to Western Oval|accessdate=5 July 2017}} The [[Old Xaverians Football Club]] of the [[Victorian Amateur Football Association]] was based there in 1993 and 1994. The oval was home to the [[South Melbourne Cricket Club]] during the summer. A remnant of the old Lake Oval structure, a grandstand built in 1926, still remains standing at the venue. It had not been used for several years, and had fallen into disrepair. Its continued existence was the subject of debate. At one stage the [[Sydney Swans]] football club showed interest in repurchasing it to be used as a museum and administrative building, while there were also calls from others to demolish the building because of its derelict state. Under the re-modelling of the venue in 2011, the stand was refurbished to house the VIS.{{cite web|url=http://www.majorprojects.vic.gov.au/our-projects/our-current-projects/state-sports-facilities|title=State Sports Facilities Project|publisher=Major Projects Victoria|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110422202013/http://www.majorprojects.vic.gov.au/our-projects/our-current-projects/state-sports-facilities|archivedate=22 April 2011|accessdate=5 July 2017}} ===Redevelopment=== Revelopment of the venue from an oval football/cricket stadium to the rectangular football stadium which became known as the Lakeside Stadium took place in 1995, when [[South Melbourne FC]] was forced out of its old home at [[Middle Park (stadium)|Middle Park]].{{Cite episode |first1=Jennifer (presenter)|last1=Keyte|first2=Brendan (reporter)|last2=Donahoe|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KLNxzPmb9s8 |title=Albert Park - The Track|access-date=5 July 2017 |series=Seven Nightly News |network=Seven Network |station=HSV Melbourne |date=29 May 1994|via=Argiri on YouTube}} The stadium was built with a capacity of 14,000 people,{{cite web|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=15|title=Lakeside Stadium|work=Austadiums|accessdate=5 July 2017}} which was achieved or approached several times in South Melbourne's history at the ground. A [[grandstand]] with an approximate capacity of 3,000 people was situated on one side, with a social club, reception centre and administrative facilities built in, while the other three sides of the ground consisted of open terraces with wooden seats. At one stage, a second two tiered stand for the outer side was proposed, but only preliminary plans were produced.{{cite web|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/redevelopment/bobjane.php|title=Bob Jane Stadium Redevelopment|work=Austadiums|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517062046/http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/redevelopment/bobjane.php|archivedate=17 May 2008|accessdate=5 July 2017}}{{better source|date=July 2017}} As well as being the home of South Melbourne FC, the venue also hosted games by the [[Socceroos]],{{cite web |first1=Thomas|last1=Esamie|first2=Greg|last2=Stock|first3=Jean-Michel|last3=Cazal|first4=Frank|last4=Scicluna|url=http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/Socceroo/1996A.html|title=Socceroo Internationals for 1996|work=OzFootball|accessdate=5 July 2017}} [[Australia national under-20 football team|Young Socceroos]], Australia's national women's team the [[Australia women's national soccer team|Matildas]],{{cite web|last=Esamie|first=Thomas|url=http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/Matildas/2006A.html|title=Matildas Internationals for 2006|work=OzFootball|accessdate=5 July 2017}} and grand finals and finals matches of the [[Victorian Premier League]] (now National Premier Leagues Victoria).{{cite web|last=Punshon|first=John|url=http://www.ozfootball.net/ark/States/VIC/2006VCR.html|title=2006 Vodafone Cup Results|work=OzFootball|accessdate=5 July 2017}} ===Athletics venue=== In May 2008, the State Government announced that Lakeside Stadium would undergo a major redevelopment, in order to accommodate an athletics track, as part of moving Athletics Victoria from [[Olympic Park, Melbourne|Olympic Park]]. The [[Victorian Institute of Sport]], Athletics Victoria and [[South Melbourne FC]] would share tenancy of the venue. Major Projects Victoria committed $60 million to the project. South Melbourne played its final match under Lakeside Stadium's previous configuration in April 2010, and construction work on the remodelled venue began in June 2010. The synthetic 8-lane athletics track was constructed to international [[IAAF]] standards. A 6-lane 60 metre warm-up track was also constructed. The remodelling also saw a [[FIFA]]-sized natural grass soccer pitch, a new electronic scoreboard, upgraded lighting, a new northern stand and new spectator amenities. The old grandstand was also renovated to accommodate offices.{{cite web|url=http://www.msac.com.au/sites/default/files/SSFP%20project%20profile%20WEB.pdf|title=State Sports Facilities Project Profile|publisher=Melbourne Sports and Aquatic Centre }} In March 2012, the stadium hosted the [[Melbourne Track Classic]]. The venue is operated by the State Sports Centre Trust, the operators of the [[Melbourne Sports and Aquatic Centre]] and the [[State Netball and Hockey Centre]]. ==See also== *[[Middle Park (stadium)]] * [[List of Australian rules football statues]], a list of Australian rules football-related statues across Australia ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.lakesidestadium.com.au/ Lakeside Stadium homepage] *{{Austadiums|id=15}} *[http://www.aroundthegrounds.bellestorie.com/lakeside/lakeside.html "Around the Grounds" - Web Documentary - Lakeside Oval] {{National Premier Leagues Victoria stadiums}} {{Melbourne landmarks}} {{AFL grounds}} {{Melbourne Victory W-League}} [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Australia]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Melbourne]] [[Category:Defunct Australian Football League grounds]] [[Category:Defunct cricket grounds in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1878]] [[Category:W-League (Australia) stadiums]] [[Category:Sydney Swans]]

page.title: List of doping cases in athletics

revision.text:
{{For|doping in sport in general|List of doping cases in sport}} {{Doping in sport sidebar |expanded=Doping-related lists}} The use of [[Use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport|performance-enhancing drugs]] (doping) is prohibited within the sport of [[athletics (sport)|athletics]]. Athletes who are found to have used such banned substances, whether through a positive drugs test, the [[biological passport]] system, an investigation or public admission, may receive a competition [[Ban (law)|ban]] for a length of time which reflects the severity of the infraction. Athletes who are found to have banned substances in their possession, or who tamper with or refuse to submit to drug testing can also receive bans from the sport. Competitive bans may also be given to athletes who test positive for prohibited [[recreational drugs]] or stimulants with little performance-enhancing effect for competitors in athletics. The sports body responsible for determining which substances are banned in athletics is the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] (WADA). Typically, any athlete who tests positive for banned substances after having served a previous ban receives a lifetime ban from the sport of athletics. Many high-profile sportspeople to receive doping bans have come from the sport of athletics, with significant past cases concerning [[Ben Johnson (sprinter)|Ben Johnson]], [[Marion Jones]] and [[Tim Montgomery]]. Furthermore, a number of athletes who underwent state-sponsored [[Doping in East Germany|doping programmes in East Germany]] between the 1960s and 1980s were competitors in athletics, but the quality of the international anti-doping work was so poor that only one East German athlete ever tested positive. Following allegations of state-sponsored [[doping in Russia]], the IAAF suspended the country's athletes from competition, including the 2016 Summer Olympics. {{Compact ToC|center=yes|refs=yes}} ==A== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%; width:95%;" |-style="background:#ccccff; class="sortable" !Name !Country !Event !Date of

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Neptune's Daughter | image = Neptune's daughter poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Edward Buzzell]] | producer = [[Jack Cummings (director)|Jack Cummings]] | writer = [[Dorothy Kingsley]] | starring = [[Esther Williams]]
[[Red Skelton]]
[[Ricardo Montalbán]]
[[Betty Garrett]] | music = [[Frank Loesser]] | cinematography = [[Charles Rosher]] | editing = [[Cotton Warburton]] | distributor = [[Metro–Goldwyn–Mayer]] | released = {{Film date|1949|06|09}} | runtime = 95 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $2,221,000{{Citation | title = The Eddie Mannix Ledger | publisher = Margaret Herrick Library, Center for Motion Picture Study | place = Los Angeles}}. | gross = $5,773,000 }} '''''Neptune's Daughter''''' is a 1949 [[Technicolor]] [[musical film|musical]] [[romantic comedy]] film released by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] starring [[Esther Williams]], [[Red Skelton]], [[Ricardo Montalbán]], [[Betty Garrett]], [[Keenan Wynn]], [[Xavier Cugat]] and [[Mel Blanc]]. It was directed by [[Edward Buzzell]], and features the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Academy Award winning song]] "[[Baby, It's Cold Outside]]" by [[Frank Loesser]]. This was the third movie that paired Williams and Ricardo Montalbán, the other two being ''[[Fiesta (1947 film)|Fiesta]]'' (1947) and ''[[On an Island with You]]'' (1948), and the second to co-star Red Skelton (after 1944's ''[[Bathing Beauty]]''). This is one of the first films to depict [[television]] use. ==Plot summary== Although she initially rejects an offer by Joe Backett to become his business partner at the Neptune swimming suit design company, aquatic ballet dancer Eve Barrett changes her mind when she considers the publicity potential of the job. One day, Joe learns that a South American polo team will be playing a big match in town, and he and Eve begin planning a swimming spectacle for the event. Eve tells her man-crazy sister and roommate Betty about the South American team, and Betty immediately seizes upon the idea of finding herself a date among the players. Meanwhile, Jose O'Rourke, the handsome playboy captain of the polo team, seeks relief for his injured arm from Jack Spratt, a bumbling masseur, who complains to Jose about his lack of success with women. During the massage, Jose gives Jack advice on how to attract women, stressing the importance of speaking to women in Spanish, which he calls the "language of love." Later, while looking for the famed South American team captain, Betty accidentally mistakes Jack for Jose. Jack does not reveal his identity to Betty and accepts her invitation to visit her at her house. On their date, Jack secretly plays a Spanish language instruction record while pretending that he is speaking romantic Spanish phrases to Betty. At the end of the evening, Betty tells Eve about her date, and Eve tries to dissuade her from pursuing a romance with any of the visiting polo players. The following day, while giving a tour of the Neptune bathing suit factory, Eve meets Jose and warns him to stay away from her sister. Jose is confused by the warning but because he is attracted to Eve, he pretends to understand and agrees to break his presumed date with Betty. When Jose asks Eve to go on the date with him, she reluctantly consents and does so only to prevent him from pursuing her sister. Despite her best attempts to make her date with Jose a failure, Eve finds him attractive and enjoys her evening. Confusion abounds the following day, when Eve's maid, Matilda, tells her that Betty has gone on another date with Jose. Furious at the news, Eve goes to Jose's apartment and demands to see her sister. She searches Jose's apartment to no avail and does not understand why Betty is not there. Later, when crooked nightclub owner Lukie Luzette learns that a man named Jose is the polo team's most valuable player, he decides to kidnap Jose and keep him out of the game to ensure that his bet against his team will pay off. Lukie sends one of his henchmen to abduct Jose, but the henchman mistakenly abducts Jack instead. Jose, meanwhile, proposes marriage to Eve, and she, having found no evidence of further wrongdoings, accepts. However, just as Eve is about to tell Betty that she intends to marry Jose, Betty informs her that she and Jose are now engaged. When Jose shows up at Eve and Betty's house, Eve, convinced that he has deceived her, shuts the door in his face. Moments later, Jose is abducted by Lukie's men and placed in captivity. Jack, meanwhile, manages to escape from his captors just as the big polo match begins. Betty, who still believes that Jack is Jose, insists that he save his team from defeat and helps him mount a horse. While Jack inadvertently scores a victory for the South American team, the police find Jose and free him. Jose arrives at the polo field in time to accept the team's trophy and to clear up Eve's confusion. Jack admits to Betty that he is an impostor, but she forgives him and assures him of her love. All ends happily as a double wedding is planned for both couples.{{cite web|title=Neptune's Daughter|url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=26038|website=AFI: Catalogue of Feature Films|publisher=American Film Institute|accessdate=24 September 2014}} ==Cast== * [[Esther Williams]] as Eve Barrett * [[Ricardo Montalbán]] as José O'Rourke * [[Red Skelton]] as Jack Spratt * [[Betty Garrett]] as Betty Barrett * [[Keenan Wynn]] as Joe Backett * [[Mel Blanc]] as Pancho * [[Xavier Cugat]] as himself * [[Ted de Corsia]] as Lukie Luzette * [[Mike Mazurki]] as Mac Mozolla * [[George Mann (vaudeville performer)|George Mann]] as Tall Wrangler * [[Frank Mitchell (actor)|Frank Mitchell]] as Little Wrangler ==Production== Although the story states off-hand that Jack Spratt is a resident of the fictional town "Clayport, California," the movie was filmed partly on location in Los Angeles, California and at [[Weeki Wachee Springs]] in Florida.http://www.weekiwacheediving.com/about.htm Some of the action in the film is depicted as taking place at [[Xavier Cugat#Restaurant|Casa Cugat]], Xavier Cugat's Mexican restaurant which was located at 848 North [[La Cienega Boulevard]] in West Hollywood.{{cite news |author= |title=Mexican Food: What Do Showbiz People Like to Eat?
