revision.text:
{{Sidebar | name = GreekAthleticArt | bodyclass = plainlist | bodystyle = {{{2|}}} | titlestyle = font-size:130%; | title = Athletics in Ancient Greek Art <div style="font-size:70%;font-weight:normal;white-space:nowrap;> | headingclass = navbox-abovebelow | headingstyle = font-size:105%; | contentstyle = padding-top:0.2em;padding-bottom:0.45em;
| heading1 = Athletic Architecture | content1 = {{Sidebar |bodystyle={{subsidebar bodystyle}} |navbar=off |headingstyle=padding-bottom:0; |contentstyle=padding-top:0; | content1 = {{startflatlist}} * [[Stadium at Nemea]] * [[Eastern pediment of the Temple of Zeus at Olympia]] * [[Nemean Baths]] * [[Stadium at Olympia]]
{{endflatlist}} }}
| heading2 = Depictions of Games | content2 = {{Sidebar |bodystyle={{subsidebar bodystyle}} |navbar=off |headingstyle=padding-bottom:0; |contentstyle=padding-top:0; | content1 = {{startflatlist}} * [[Kylix depicting Pentathletes]] * [[Kleophrades terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora]] * [[Bronze Diskos Thrower Statue]] * [[Akrotiri Boxer Fresco]] * [[Euphiletos Painter Panathenaic prize amphora]] * [[Drinking cup (kylix) depicting athletic combats by Onesimos]] * [[Bronze Statuette of Athletic Spartan Girl]] * [[Boxing Siana Cup]] * [[Boeotian Dancer's Group Kothon, Black Figure Tripod, 6th Century B.C.]]
{{endflatlist}} }}
| heading3 = Athletic Dedications | content3 = {{Sidebar |bodystyle={{subsidebar bodystyle}} |navbar=off |headingstyle=padding-bottom:0; |contentstyle=padding-top:0; | content1 = {{startflatlist}} * [[Apobates Base]] * [[Boxer Stele Fragment from Kerameikos]] * [[Bronze Discus: Votive Dedication of Asklepiades]]
{{endflatlist}}
}} }} [[File:Stadion of Nemea.jpg|thumb|[[Stadium at Nemea|Stadion of Nemea]]]] [[File:The Boxers Fresco, from Akrotiri, Thera (Santorini), Minoan Civilization, 16th Century BC, National Archaeological Museum of Athens (14112030702).jpg|thumb|297x297px|[[Akrotiri Boxer Fresco]] from Thera]]
Athletics were an important part of the cultural life of Ancient Greeks. Depictions of boxing and [[bull-leaping]] can be found back to the [[Bronze Age Greece|Bronze Age]]. Buildings were created for the sole use of athletics including [[Stadion (running race)|stadions]], [[palaestra]], and [[Gymnasium (ancient Greece)|gymnasiums]]. Starting in the [[Archaic Greece|Archaic Period]], [[Panhellenic Games]], including the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]], begin taking place each year. These games gave people from all over Greece the chance to gain fame for their athletic prowess. Athletics in Greece became one of the most commonly depicted scenes of everyday life in their art.
== Architecture relating to athletics == {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2017}}
As the site of the [[Ancient Olympic Games|Olympic Games]], the architecture of [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]] is heavily influenced by the theme of athletics. The temple of Zeus, for example, is decorated with a frieze containing the 12 labors of [[Heracles]], who is believed to be the founder of the Olympic Games, and a [[Eastern Pediment of the Temple of Zeus at Olympia|pediment]] depicting the myth of [[Pelops]], another origin tale of the Olympics. [[File:Stadium at Olympia 2013.JPG|thumb|Birth of the Olympic Games in the Stadium at Olympia]] The main site of where the Olympic Games took place was the [[Stadium at Olympia]] which is located to the east of the [[Temple of Zeus, Olympia|sanctuary of Zeus]]. The physical landmarks of the Stadium are 212.54 meters long and 30–34 meters wide, and it served mainly for running races that determined the fastest person in the world. The track was made of hard-packed clay to serve as traction for the people competing in the running events.
The site of Nemea showcase both the practical and ceremonial use of athletic architecture in the early Hellenistic monumentalization of Panhellenic sanctuaries. The bath house [[Nemean Baths]] contains a western room with basin baths and an eastern plunge bath. The western basin room is common of 4th century baths throughout Greece and was likely place where visiting athletes could wash themselves during their stay. The eastern plunge bath however, is one of only 4 others in Greece, all of which have been found at Panhellenic ritual sites. Though its exact function is unknown, its public nature suggests that it may have had a ritual component in the athletic games or ceremonies. Nemea also housed a stadium, where athletes would participate in games, specifically the stadion (running event).
== Depictions of Games ==
During the [[Bronze Age]], the [[Minoan civilization|Minoans]] practiced several sports, including wrestling, bull jumping, acrobatics, and boxing. This is apparent in multiple pieces of art, ranging from frescoes to pottery. The youth of the boys in the [[Akrotiri Boxer Fresco]] hints that athletes began training very early on in life, suggesting that sports were extremely important to Minoan society. It has even been suggested that athletics played a religious role in society due to their widespread practice. Finally, the youth of athletes in many pieces of artwork indicates that athletic competition may have been a rite if passage into adulthood for the Minoans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fhw.gr/olympics/ancient/en/102.html|title=OLYMPIC GAMES|website=www.fhw.gr}}</ref>
One of the most popular and famous combat sports in Ancient Greece was [[boxing]]. Boxing in Ancient Greece was far less regulated than modern boxing, with opponents chosen at random, regardless of weight or age, and matches lasting until one of the competitors admitted defeat or was left unconscious.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/Olympics/boxing.html|title=Ancient Sports: Boxing|website=www.perseus.tufts.edu|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref> Fighters were often left disfigured; for example, one boxing injury commonly depicted was the [[cauliflower ear]], which was depicted notably in the [[Boxer Stele Fragment from Kerameikos|Boxer Stele from Kerameikos]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/745332893|title=Greek art and archaeology : a new history, c. 2500-c. 150 BCE|last=T.,|first=Neer, Richard|isbn=9780500288771|location=New York|oclc=745332893}}</ref> Many who participated in these ancient boxing matches were gravely injured or even killed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fightland.vice.com/blog/the-bloody-deadly-heavy-fights-of-ancient-greece|title=The Bloody, Deadly, Heavy Fights of Ancient Greece {{!}} FIGHTLAND|work=Fightland|access-date=2017-12-07|language=en}}</ref> Despite this, boxing was highly popular among the Ancient Grecian population and therefore was frequently featured on works of art. Another notable depiction of an ancient boxer is [[Boxer at Rest]], also known as Terme Boxer, who has just finished a match.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/blogs/now-at-the-met/features/2013/the-boxer|title=The Boxer: An Ancient Masterpiece Comes to the Met|website=The Metropolitan Museum of Art, i.e. The Met Museum|access-date=2017-12-07}}</ref> For example, the [[Boeotian Dancer's Group Kothon, Black Figure Tripod, 6th Century B.C.|kothon, black-figure tripod by the Boeotian Dancer's Group]] features two men engaged in a boxing match on one of its legs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://library.artstor.org/#/asset/AMICO_DALLAS_103842516|title=Artstor|last=Artstor|website=library.artstor.org|access-date=2017-12-04}}</ref>
Athletic events, particularly [[Panhellenic festivals]], brought drew both athletes and spectators. Occurrences of athletic competitions were first recorded by [[Homer]] in the [[Iliad]]. As a result, competitions had ties with war and military training.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.credoreference.com/content/entry/abccliow/development_of_the_concept_of_sport_in_the_greek_world/0|title=Development of the Concept of Sport in the Greek World - World History Encyclopedia - Credo Reference|website=search.credoreference.com}}</ref> Depictions of athletic events in ancient art sometimes show the athletes wearing armor in order to illustrate the connection between athletes and warriors.
Depictions of athletic events were also portrayed on pieces of pottery used in everyday life. Artists like [[Onesimos (vase painter)|Onesimos]] and the [[Foundry Painter]] depicted events such as [[Pankration|pancration]] scenes and wrestling matches on kylixes which were then used at [[symposium]]s or male drinking parties. Both of these painters used the red-figure technique, developed in Athens in 530 B.C., in their work and this technique allowed them to have greater freedom to express movement, emotion, and anatomy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/vase/hd_vase.htm|title=Athenian Vase Painting: Black- and Red-Figure Techniques {{!}} Essay {{!}} Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History {{!}} The Metropolitan Museum of Art|last=Art|first=Author: Department of Greek and Roman|website=The Met’s Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
The depictions of Athletic events in Art expanded as major athletic events also expanded. In 708 BCE, the [[pentathlon]] was added to the Olympic games. Since this event required the skills for five different events ([[Discus throw|discus]], [[Javelin throw|javelin]], [[long jump]], [[running]], and [[wrestling]]) these athletes were held in high regard among society.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ancientolympics.arts.kuleuven.be/eng/TC006EN.html|title=Ancient Olympics|website=ancientolympics.arts.kuleuven.be|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref> It became common to have a [[Kylix depicting Pentathletes|kylix]] or an amphora depict these events, and in turn, it praised the athletes by leaving their legacy in the art.
The [[Kleophrades Terracotta Panathenaic Prize Amphora|Kleophrades terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora]] (ca. 500 BCE) provides an example of recognition for success in athletic endeavors. At the [[Panathenaic Games]], victors would be awarded a prize amphora filled with a luxury good like olive oil. The amphora itself would depict [[Athena Promachos]], or Athena as a military leader directing troops into battle, and the athletic event in which the victor competed. Recognition for athletic endeavors and success by depicting the event itself as this Panathenaic prize amphora does highlights just how important athleticism was to the Ancient Greeks. Another example of the many Panathenaic Prize Amphoras is the [[Euphiletos Painter Panathenaic Amphora]] (530 BC). Painted in black figure, this Panathenaic amphora depicts a [[Stadion (running race)|stadion]] from Panathenaic games. Like other prize amphora, this amphora serves to emphasize athleticism and the victors of these events. [[File:Terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora MET DT5498.jpg|thumb|207x207px|[[Kleophrades terracotta Panathenaic prize amphora|Panthenaic Amphora By Kleophrades Painter]]]] Descriptions of women’s sport during Archaic Period mainly come from literary sources, and there are a few examples of female sporting events. One of the most popular forms of physical activity for ancient Greek women is running.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=D.|first=Mills, Brett|date=|title=Women of Ancient Greece: Participating in Sport?.|url=https://eric.ed.gov/?id=ED370951|language=en}}</ref> The [[Bronze Statuette of Athletic Spartan Girl|bronze statuettes of athletic Spartan girl]], which depicts Spartan young women involving in racing games, provide material evidence to the accounts of different women’s races in ancient Greece.
== Athletic Dedications ==
The prominence of athletic subject material in Greek art is no coincidence. Even statuary, called Athletic Dedications, arose as a way to immortalize Greek athletes and athletic games. Athletic events and art were so closely related that a common practice of athletes was to commemorate their victories with artistic dedications. One example of this would be the marble [[Apobates Base]] which commemorates victory in a chariot race at the [[Panathenaic Games]]. A competitor would erect a dedication to celebrate an athletic victory and place it in a sanctuary or Panhellenic site. These dedications were an artistic celebration of athletic prowess which every Greek could observe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/ancient-art-civilizations/greek-art/beginners-guide-greece/a/olympic-games|title=Khan Academy|website=Khan Academy}}</ref> [[File:AGMA Victorious Apobates 7305.jpg|thumb|[[Apobates Base]]]] As part of the games taking place at [[Olympia, Greece|Olympia]], many individuals competed in the pentathlon, a competition consisting of five events. The [[Ancient Olympic pentathlon|Ancient Olympic Pentathlon]] consisted of the [[discus throw]], [[long jump]]s with weights attached to their feet, [[javelin throw]], [[running]], and [[wrestling]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/Olympics/pentathlon.html|title=Ancient Olympic Events|last=|first=|date=|website=www.perseus.tufts.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-03}}</ref> Many victors of the pentathlon would go on to receive prizes such as exclusive items that were made specifically for the victor. For example, the amphorae of the [[Panathenaic Games]], often filled with expensive olive oil, featured [[Athena]] standing with a sword and shield to represent their victory in the games.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=von Bothmer|first=Dietrich|date=|title=A Panathenaic Amphora|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/pubs/bulletins/1/pdf/3257530.pdf.bannered.pdf|journal=Metropolitan Museum of Art|volume=|pages=53–54}}</ref> Because the Olympics were dedicated to [[Zeus]], often these prizes would become votive dedications to him.<ref name=":0" />
The [[Bronze Diskos Thrower Statue|Bronze Diskos Thrower]] (''Discobolus'') was a rare commodity that came from a time in which not many pieces survived: the end of the Persian Wars. The piece itself still exhibits many traits of archaic art, despite coming from the early Classical period (480 - 460 BCE). The athlete in the statue was a participant of diskos throwing, a very popular event in Ancient Greece and even modern day Olympics.
== References ==
<references />
[[Category:Ancient Greek athletic art]] [[Category:Sport in antiquity]] [[Category:Sports in art|Ancient Greek]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 6 sources and tagging 2 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
'''Sports teams named''' "'''Redskins'''" are part of the larger [[Native American mascot controversy]] regarding the use of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] names, images and symbols by non-native sports teams. Teams of this name have received particular public attention due to the fact that the term "[[redskin (slang)|redskin]]" is now generally regarded as disparaging and offensive.<ref name=OED>{{Cite OED|redskin}}</ref><ref name=mw>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/redskin|title=Definition of REDSKIN|publisher=Merriam-Webster| quote=Definition of REDSKIN (usually offensive): american indian| accessdate=November 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name=ahd>{{cite book|url=http://ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=redskin| title=The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, Fifth Edition| year=2011| publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Publishing Company| quote=n. ''Offensive Slang'' Used as a disparaging term for a Native American.| accessdate=November 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name=dictionaryreference>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/redskin|title=Redskin|publisher=Dictionary.com| quote=noun, ''Slang: Often Disparaging and Offensive.'' 1. a North American Indian.| accessdate=November 7, 2014}}</ref><ref name=collins>{{cite web|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/redskin?|title=Definition of redskin|publisher=Collins English Dictionary}}</ref>
The most prominent team of this name is the [[Washington Redskins]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL), which has been at the center of an [[Washington Redskins name controversy|ongoing controversy]] and campaigns to change the name. Various high school and youth teams have also used the name, though the number has been steadily declining. The college sports teams using the name changed voluntarily prior to the [[NCAA Native American mascot decision]] in 2005; the [[University of Utah]] became [[Utah Utes]] in 1972, [[Miami University| Miami University of Ohio]] became the [[Miami RedHawks|RedHawks]] in 1997 and the [[Southern Nazarene University]] became the [[Southern Nazarene Crimson Storm|Crimson Storm]] in 1998. Defenders of the Redskins name, both nationally and locally, cite their tradition, and the pride they feel in their team, while calls for change are often dismissed as [[political correctness]].
==Term== {{main|Redskin (slang)}}
''Redskin'' is one of the color terms for race that emerged in the [[colonial history of the United States|colonial period]] as Native Americans encountered people who called themselves "white" and their slaves "black". The use of "red" as an identifier by Native Americans for themselves emerged in the context of Indian-European diplomacy in the southeastern region of North America, before later being adopted by Europeans.<ref name="Shoemaker.1997">{{cite journal |url=https://peopleofonefire.com/how_indians_got_to_be_red.pdf | last=Shoemaker| first=Nancy| title=How Indians Got to Be Red| journal=The American Historical Review| volume=102| issue=3| date=1997| pages=625–644| doi=10.2307/2171504}}</ref>{{rp|627–8}} The choice of red rather than other colors may have been due to cultural associations, rather than skin color; the red/white dichotomy having symbolic meaning for Native Americans in the southeast.<ref name="Shoemaker.1997"/>{{rp|632}} Usage in the northeast region by Europeans may have been largely limited to descriptions of tribes such as the [[Beothuk]] of Newfoundland, whose practice of painting their bodies and possessions with [[red ochre]] led Europeans to refer to them as "Red Indians".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.historica.ca/the_beothuk.php |title=The Beothuk Indians - "Newfoundland's Red Ochre People" |work=Historica Canadiana |date=6 December 2006}}</ref> The origin of the term "redskin" is debated. It may have first been used by Native Americans to refer to themselves,<ref name="Goddard.2005">{{cite journal |last=Goddard |first=Ives |authorlink=Ives Goddard |date=2005 |title=“I AM A RED-SKIN”: The Adoption of a Native American Expression (1769–1826) |url=http://esq.h-cdn.co/assets/cm/15/06/54d44abb4e540_-_redskin.pdf |journal=[[Native American studies#Academic journals|European Review of Native American Studies]] |volume=19 |issue=2}}</ref>{{rp|1–4}} or by colonial settlers in the context of violence against Native Americans, in particular the paying of bounties for Indian scalps.<ref>{{cite book| last=Dunbar-Ortiz| first=Roxanne| title=An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States| year=2014| publisher=[[Beacon Press]]| url=https://zinnedproject.org/materials/indigenous-peoples-history-of-the-us/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ending the Legacy of Racism in Sports & the Era of Harmful "Indian" Sports Mascots|url=http://www.ncai.org/resources/ncai-publications/Ending_the_Legacy_of_Racism.pdf|publisher=National Congress of American Indians|accessdate=29 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="Taylor">{{cite new| url=http://lancasteronline.com/news/redskin-a-fun-team-name-or-racial-epithet/article_da4db853-43e8-5a25-aae8-714425420e68.html| title='Redskin': A fun team name or racial epithet?| date=November 6, 2013| accessdate=May 9, 2017 |author=Sudip Bhatttacharya| quote=Michael Taylor, a Seneca Indian and an assistant professor at Colgate University: 'The term "redskin" comes from the Colonial era, when some Native Americans were killed in clashes with newly arrived settlers and others were hunted down for a bounty.'| publisher=LNP MEDIA GROUP, Inc.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last=Stannard| first=David E| title=American Holocaust: The Conquest of the New World| publisher=Oxford Press| year=1992| isbn=0-19-508557-4| url=https://books.google.com/books/about/American_Holocaust.html?id=RzFsODcGjfcC| page=116}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Flintlock_and_tomahawk.html?id=0IYGAQAAIAAJ| title=Flintlock and Tomahawk: New England in King Philip's War| first=Douglas Edward| last=Leach| publisher=WW Norton & Company| location=New York| year=1958| page=237}}</ref> The oldest known use dates to 1769, in a translation from the French ''peau rouge''. This and other early quotations are from Native American speakers.<ref name=OED/> By 1862, the term was being used disparagingly.<ref name=WaPo>{{cite news |last= Shapira |first= Ian |date= May 19, 2016 |title= A brief history of the word 'redskin' and how it became a source of controversy|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/a-brief-history-of-the-word-redskin-and-how-it-became-a-source-of-controversy/2016/05/19/062cd618-187f-11e6-9e16-2e5a123aac62_story.html |work= [[The Washington Post]] |access-date= September 13, 2017 }}</ref>
In the early 20th century, sports teams began adopting Native American-themed names, including "Redskins". [[Miami University]] in Ohio and [[Huntley High School]] in [[Huntley, Illinois]] started using the "Redskins" name in 1928.<ref>{{cite book |last= Stapleton |first= Bruce |year = 2001 |title= Redskins: Racial Slur Or Symbol of Success?|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Isj8cHpz3zQC&pg=PA116&dq=redskins+%22high+school%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjFh92XvqLWAhVJ5iYKHROPBbUQ6AEIKzAB#v=onepage&q=redskins%20%22high%20school%22&f=false |publisher= Writer's Club Press |page= 115 |isbn=0595171672 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Guiliano|first= Jennifer |year=2015 |title= Indian Spectacle: College Mascots and the Anxiety of Modern America |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=nzx_CgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false| publisher= Rutgers University Press|pages= 59–69|isbn= 0813565561}}</ref> In 1933, the Boston Braves of the [[National Football League]] changed their name to the [[Boston Redskins]]; the team states that this was done in honor of Native Americans on the team, although owner [[George Preston Marshall]] said at the time it was done to avoid confusion with the [[Boston Braves (baseball)|Boston Braves]] baseball team. This team has been the [[Washington Redskins]] since relocating to [[Washington, D.C.]] in 1937.<ref name=WaPo/>
==Controversy== {{main|Native American mascot controversy}} Native American mascots are often discussed in the media in terms of offensiveness, which reduces it to feelings and opinions, and prevents full understanding of the history and context of the use of Native American names and images and why their use by sports teams should be eliminated.<ref name="handbook">{{cite book|editor=C. Richard King|title=The Native American Mascot Controversy: A Handbook|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Lanham, Maryland|year=2010|isbn=978-0-8108-6731-4|page=1}}</ref> Social science research says that sports mascots and images, rather than being mere entertainment, are important symbols with deeper psychological and social effects.<ref>{{cite journal|author=[[Stephanie Fryberg|Stephanie A. Fryberg]]|title=Of Warrior Chiefs and Indian Princesses: The Psychological Consequences of American Indian Mascots|work=Basic and applied social psychology|date=September 2008|volume=30 | issue = 3|page=208|doi=10.1080/01973530802375003}}</ref> Stereotyping may directly affect the academic performance and self-esteem of Native American youth, whose people face high rates of suicide, unemployment, and poverty.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nyti.ms/1DNrWb2|title=It's Not Me, It's You|author=Annie Murphy Paul|date=October 6, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=February 11, 2013}}</ref> Euro-Americans exposed to mascots may be more likely to believe not only that such stereotypes are true, but that Native Americans have no identity beyond these stereotypes.<ref name="bias">{{cite journal|author=John Chaney|title=Do American Indian Mascots = American Indian People? Examining Implicit Bias towards American Indian People and American Indian Mascots|work=American Indian and Alaska native mental health research |date=January 1, 2011|volume=18 | issue = 1|page=42}}</ref> Research demonstrates the harm of stereotyping, with studies showing that exposure to any stereotypes increased the likelihood of stereotypical thinking with regard to other groups.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Chu Kim-Prieto|title=Effect of Exposure to an American Indian Mascot on the Tendency to Stereotype a Different Minority Group|journal=Journal of Applied Social Psychology|date=March 2010|volume=40|number=3|page=534|doi=10.1111/j.1559-1816.2010.00586.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-hidden-brain/201003/native-american-imagery-sports-mascots-new-problem|work=Psychology Today|title=Native American imagery as sports mascots: A new problem|date=March 25, 2010|author=Shankar Vedantam|accessdate=February 5, 2013}}</ref>
In 2005, the [[American Psychological Association]] issued a resolution "Recommending the Immediate Retirement of American Indian Mascots, Symbols, Images, and Personalities by Schools, Colleges, Universities, Athletic Teams, and Organizations" due to the harm done by creating a hostile environment, the negative impact on the self-esteem of American Indian children, and discrimination that may violate civil rights. It also impacts non-natives by reinforcing mainstream stereotypes, preventing learning about Native American culture. The APA states that stereotyping is disrespectful of the beliefs, traditions and values of Native Americans.<ref name=APA>{{cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/pi/oema/resources/indian-mascots.aspx|title=Summary of the Resolution Recommending Retirement of American Indian Mascots|publisher=American Psychological Association|year=2005}}</ref> Similar resolutions have been adopted by the North American Society for the Sociology of Sport,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nasss.org/nasss-native-american-imagery-resolution/| title=NASSS Native American Imagery Resolution| date=October 28, 2005| publisher=North American Society for the Sociology of Sport| accessdate=February 5, 2017}}</ref> the [[American Sociological Association]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asanet.org/about/Council_Statements/use_of_native_american_nicknames_logos_and_mascots.cfm |title=Statement by the Council of the American Sociological Association on Discontinuing the Use of Native American Nicknames, Logos and Mascots in Sport |publisher=American Sociological Association |date=March 6, 2007 |accessdate=2013-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221184942/http://asanet.org/about/Council_Statements/use_of_native_american_nicknames_logos_and_mascots.cfm |archivedate=February 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref> the [[American Counseling Association]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.counseling.org/docs/resolutions/resolutions-2001-present.pdf?sfvrsn=2 |publisher=American Counseling Association |title=Opposition to Use of Stereotypical Native American Images as Sports Symbols and Mascots |year=2001 |accessdate=2013-01-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130915125336/http://counseling.org/docs/resolutions/resolutions-2001-present.pdf?sfvrsn=2 |archivedate=2013-09-15 |df= }}</ref> and the [[American Anthropological Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/rdcms-aaa/files/production/public/FileDownloads/pdfs/issues/press/upload/Sports-Mascot-Resolution-Release-Final.pdf |title=AAA Calls on Sports Organizations to Denounce Inappropriate American Indian Mascots |date=March 25, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161204135245/http://s3.amazonaws.com/rdcms-aaa/files/production/public/FileDownloads/pdfs/issues/press/upload/Sports-Mascot-Resolution-Release-Final.pdf |archivedate=December 4, 2016 |df= }}</ref> In a 2005 report on the status of Native American students, the [[National Education Association]] included the elimination of Indian mascots and sports team names as one of its recommendations.<ref>{{citation|title=A Report on the Status of American Indians and Alaska Natives in Education|first=|author=Trujillo,Octaviana (Ph.D.)|author2=Alston, Denise (Ph.D.)|year=2005|publisher=National Education Association}}</ref>
==Washington Redskins== {{main|Washington Redskins name controversy}} Native American individuals, tribes and organizations have been questioning the use of the name and image for decades. In the 1940s the [[National Congress of American Indians]] (NCAI) created a campaign to eliminate negative stereotyping of Native American people in the media. Over time, the campaign began to focus on Indian names and mascots in sports.<ref>{{cite journal|author=J Gordon Hylton|title=BEFORE THE REDSKINS WERE THE REDSKINS: THE USE OF NATIVE AMERICAN TEAM NAMES IN THE FORMATIVE ERA OF AMERICAN SPORTS, 1857–1933|publisher=North Dakota law review| date=2010-01-01| volume=86| page=879}}</ref> The NCAI maintains that teams with Indian mascots [[Defamation|defame]] Native American people, perpetuate negative stereotypes and demeaning their native traditions and rituals.<ref name="NCAI">{{cite web|url=http://www.ncai.org/policy-issues/community-and-culture/anti-defamation-mascots|title=Anti-Defamation and Mascots|publisher=National Congress of American Indians|accessdate=12 January 2013}}</ref> The NCAI issued a new report in 2013 summarizing opposition to Indian mascots and team names generally, and the Washington Redskins in particular.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncai.org/news/articles/2013/10/10/ncai-releases-report-on-history-and-legacy-of-washington-s-harmful-indian-sports-mascot|title=NCAI Releases Report on History and Legacy of Washington's Harmful "Indian" Sports Mascot|accessdate=October 11, 2013}}</ref>
In response to the continued controversy, the team owner Dan Snyder sent an open letter to fans that was published in ''The Washington Post'' on October 9, 2013. In the letter Snyder states that the most important meaning of the name Redskins is the association that fans have to memories of their personal history with the team. Snyder also states that the name was chosen in 1933 to honor Native Americans in general and the coach and four players at that time who were Native American; and that in 1971 the then coach George Allen consulted with the Red Cloud Athletic Fund on the Pine Ridge reservation when designing the logo.<ref name="snyder">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/letter-from-washington-redskins-owner-dan-snyder-to-fans/2013/10/09/e7670ba0-30fe-11e3-8627-c5d7de0a046b_story.html|title=Letter from Washington Redskins owner Dan Snyder to fans|work=The Washington Post|date=October 9, 2013|author=Michelle Boorstein}}</ref>
In June 2014, the [[Trademark Trial and Appeal Board]] (TTAB) voted to cancel the six trademarks held by the team in a two to one decision that held that the term "redskins" is disparaging to a "substantial composite of Native Americans".<ref name="ttabvue.uspto.gov">{{cite news|url=http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pno=92046185&pty=CAN&eno=199|title=USPTO TTABVUE. Proceeding Number 92046185|publisher=''United States Patent and Trademark Office''|date=June 18, 2014|accessdate=June 18, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/19/sports/football/us-patent-office-cancels-redskins-trademark-registration.html?_r=0|title=U.S. Patent Office Cancels Redskins Trademark Registration|author1=Ken Belson|author2=Edward Wyatt|date=June 18, 2014|newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> In a separate case ([[Matal v. Tam]]) an Asian-American rock band, "[[The Slants]]" appealed the denial of a trademark for their name.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/supreme-court-asked-hear-two-cases-could-sack-washington-redskins-n562101| title=Supreme Court Asked to Hear Two Cases That Could Sack Washington 'Redskins' Name| author=Alex Johnson| date=April 25, 2016| publisher=NBC News}}</ref> In June 2017, the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] ruled in favor of Tam, the majority opinion stating "the disparagement clause violates the First Amendment's Free Speech Clause. Contrary to the Government's contention, trademarks are private, not government speech."<ref>{{cite web|title=15-1293 Martal V. Tam|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/16pdf/15-1293_1o13.pdf|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref> Both the Native American petitioners and the Justice Department have withdrawn from any further litigation now that the Supreme Court has rendered the legal issue moot, clearing the way for the restoration of the Redskin's trademarks.<ref>{{cite news|title=Washington Redskins win trademark fight over the team's name|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/2017/06/29/a26f52f0-5cf6-11e7-9fc6-c7ef4bc58d13_story.html|accessdate=30 June 2017| author1=Ian Shapira| author2=Ann E. Marimow| date=June 29, 2017| newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref> While Dan Snyder hailed this decision as a victory, this does not alter the prior legal determination that the name is disparaging.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/supreme-court-rejecting-trademarks-that-disparage-others-violates-the-first-amendment/2017/06/19/26a33ffa-23b3-11e7-a1b3-faff0034e2de_story.html| title=Supreme Court: Rejecting trademarks that 'disparage' others violates the First Amendment | publisher=The Washington Post| author=Robert Barnes| date=June 19, 2017}}</ref>
==High schools== The number of high schools using the Redskins name has been in steady decline, 40% having had local efforts to change the name. Between 1988 and April 2013, 28 high schools in 18 states had done so.<ref name="CNSMaryland.20130402">{{cite news|url=http://cnsmaryland.org/interactives/other-redskins/| title=The Other Redskins| agency=Capitol News Service| publisher=[[Philip Merrill College of Journalism]]| first=Kelyn| last=Soong| date=April 2, 2013| accessdate=December 20, 2017}}</ref> By December, 2017, the number of high school "Redskins" had continued to decline from 62 to 49,<ref name="CNSMaryland.20171219">{{cite news| first1=Adam| last1=Zielonka| first2=Dylan| last2=Sinn| title=More than a Mascot: Redskins High Schools| agency=Capital News Service| publisher=[[Philip Merrill College of Journalism]]| date=December 19, 2017| url=http://cnsmaryland.org/more-than-a-mascot-redskins-high-schools/ | accessdate=December 20, 2017}}</ref> including four affected by a 2015 California law.<ref name="Melanie Mason">{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-me-pc-redskins-mascot-banned-20151011-story.html| title=California schools barred from using 'Redskins' as team name or mascot| author=Melanie Mason| date=October 11, 2015| newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>
===Role in the national controversy=== On its official website in early 2013, the [[Washington Redskins]] posted articles referring to high school teams using the same name (and often the same logo). The athletic director of [[Coshocton High School]] in [[Coshocton, Ohio]] is quoted as saying, "We are very proud of our athletic teams and very proud to be called Redskins!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redskins.com/news-and-events/article-1/We-Are-Very-Proud-To-Be-Called-Redskins/d4d7c05d-be39-4a27-9244-d06cfae46797|title=We Are Very Proud To Be Called Redskins|date=February 11, 2013|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> The principal of [[McLoud High School]] in [[McLoud, Oklahoma]] says that not only students, but the local Native American population takes pride in the name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redskins.com/news-and-events/article-1/McLoud-Our-Community-Is-Proud-Of-Our-Name/cc374c86-5782-4bb2-a0e0-d8c4c9f313b8|title=McLoud: 'Our Community Is Proud Of Our Name'|date=February 12, 2013|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> The coach at [[Lamar High School (Houston, Texas)|Lamar High School]] in [[Houston]], [[Texas]] says, "Our school is 75 years old and there's a lot of pride in it," he explained. "I think it's a great mascot, as all of the traits of a Redskins [[warrior]] are something to be admired."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redskins.com/news-and-events/article-1/Lamar-Once-A-Redskin-Always-A-Redskin/9ee6ad61-018f-42e0-b3d9-eb72a8b638e9|title=Lamar: 'Once A Redskin, Always A Redskin.'|date=February 13, 2013|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref>
Advocates for the Washington team often refer to the three majority Native American schools, concluding that because some Native Americans use the name to refer to themselves, it is not insulting.<ref name=Spoken>{{cite web |author=Rick Reilly |title=Have the people spoken? |url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9689220/redskins-name-change-not-easy-sounds/ |website=ESPN |accessdate=October 15, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130919035546/http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/9689220/redskins-name-change-not-easy-sounds |archivedate=September 19, 2013 |deadurl=no |date=September 18, 2013 |df= }}</ref> However, the principal of one of these, [[Red Mesa High School]] in [[Teec Nos Pos, Arizona]], said that use of the word outside American Indian communities should be avoided because it could perpetuate "the legacy of negativity that the term has created."<ref name="Michelle Peirano">{{cite news|url=http://cronkitenewsonline.com/2013/05/in-debate-over-redskins-name-is-the-r-word-for-racism-or-respect/|title=In debate over Redskins name, is the 'R-word' for racism or respect?|date=May 1, 2013|author=Michelle Peirano|newspaper=Cronkite News|accessdate=2014-02-06}}</ref> Wellpinit High School on the [[Spokane people|Spokane Indian]] Reservation in Washington wants nothing to do with the national controversy, seeing Redskins as the traditional name they have used for their team. However, they do not accept their usage as a justification for anyone else using the name.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/redskins-controversy-high-school-with-debated-name-just-wants-to-be-left-alone/| title=Redskins controversy? High school with debated name just wants to be left alone| date=June 30, 2014| newspaper=The Seattle Times}}</ref>
===Recent changes=== The Cooperstown Central School Board of Education in [[Cooperstown, New York]] voted 6-1 on March 6, 2013 to remove the Redskins mascot from its interscholastic athletic, extracurricular and academic programs. The move was prompted by a vote by the student body, asking that the mascot be changed. The [[Oneida Indian Nation]] was so moved by the actions of the Cooperstown students, that a letter by Oneida Nation Representative Ray Halbritter was written to the students, commending their decision and offering to make a contribution to help offset the cost of changing mascots.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oneidaindiannation.com/pressroom/latestnews/Oneida-Indian-Nation-Congratulates-Cooperstown-Central-School-Board-for-Voting-to-Remove-Redskins-Mascot-196067191.html|title=Oneida Indian Nation Congratulates Cooperstown Central School Board for Voting to Remove Redskins Mascot|date=March 7, 2013|accessdate=March 14, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020014424/http://www.oneidaindiannation.com/pressroom/latestnews/Oneida-Indian-Nation-Congratulates-Cooperstown-Central-School-Board-for-Voting-to-Remove-Redskins-Mascot-196067191.html|archivedate=October 20, 2014|df=}}</ref>
On June 24, 2013 school board members of the [[Port Townsend High School]] in [[Port Townsend, Washington]] voted to replace its "Redskins" nickname, logo, and mascot (used since 1926) due to its divisive nature.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.peninsuladailynews.com/article/20130625/NEWS/130629988/redskins-dropped-as-team-name-and-mascot-for-port-townsend-high|title='Redskins' dropped as team name and mascot for Port Townsend High School|author=Charlie Bermant|newspaper=Peninsula Daily News|date=June 25, 2013}}</ref> In April 2014 the students selected Red Hawks as their new team name. The next step will be to select new graphics to replace the old.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.peninsuladailynews.com/article/20140410/news/304109981/port-townsend-students-pick-red-hawks-as-high-school-8217-s-new|title=Port Townsend students pick Red Hawks as high school's new mascot|author=Charlie Bermant|date=April 10, 2014|newspaper=Peninsula Daily News}}</ref>
[[Ledgemont High School]] in [[Thompson Township, Geauga County, Ohio]] which had used the name closed in 2014.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.news-herald.com/article/hr/20140319/NEWS/140319565 |title=Ledgemont School Board votes to close high school building |author=Jean Bonchak |publisher=The News-Herald |date=March 19, 2014}}</ref>
Lamar High School in [[Houston, Texas]] was one of the four schools required to change their mascots as a result of a vote by the Houston Independent School District to remove culturally insensitive names.<ref name="Troy Blevins">{{cite news|url=http://m.click2houston.com/news/houston-isd-votes-to-change-school-mascots/-/16714936/23463546/-/n5jf59z/-/index.html|title=Houston ISD votes to change school mascots|author=Troy Blevins|publisher=KPRC}}</ref> Lamar became the Texans in April, 2014.<ref name="Ericka Mellon">{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/New-HISD-mascots-Huskies-Wolf-Pack-Texans-5403772.php|title=New HISD mascots: Huskies, Wolf Pack, Texans|author=Ericka Mellon|date=April 15, 2014|newspaper=The Houston Chronicle}}</ref>
On December 8, 2014 the [[Oklahoma City]] School Board voted unanimously to remove Redskins as the nickname for [[Oklahoma City Public Schools|Capitol Hill High School]]. The vote came in response to pleas from students and teachers who found the term offensive.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/09/us-usa-oklahoma-redskins-idUSKBN0JN27T20141209| title=Oklahoma City high school drops the name 'Redskins' for its team| author=Heide Brandes| publisher=Reuters| date=December 10, 2014}}</ref> The following day some students of the high school upset by the change protested the school board decision.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://kfor.com/2014/12/10/oklahoma-city-students-protest-mascot-change/| title=Update: Oklahoma City students protest mascot change| date=December 10, 2014| publisher=KFOR-TV| author=L. Noland}}</ref> On January 6, 2015, the school board held an information forum at which a panel of Native American community leaders presented the reasons for the decision, including the derogatory nature of the term. Some members of the audience walked out during the presentation, and one alumni called the presentation "[[propaganda]]" and asserted his opposition to changing the name. Another alumni stated that if any Native Americans did not like the name Redskins they should go to a native school.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://okgazette.com/2015/01/06/opinions-over-mascot-clash-at-public-forum/| title=Opinions over mascot clash at public forum| author=Ben Felder| newspaper=Oklahoma Gazette| date=January 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://newsok.com/american-indian-parents-group-holds-forum-on-capitol-hill-mascot-name-change/article/5382403| title=American Indian parents' group holds forum on Capitol Hill mascot name change| author=Graham Lee Brewer| date=January 6, 2015| publisher=NewsOK}}</ref> A committee selected four possible replacements; Red Hawks, Red Wolves, War Eagles and Nations, with the final decision to be made by a vote of Capitol Hill Students. Names such as Chieftains and Warriors, although favored by alumni on the committee, were not selected as continuing the linkage to Native Americans.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://newsok.com/four-possible-mascot-names-chosen-for-oklahoma-citys-capitol-hill-high-school/article/5396836| title= Four possible mascot names chosen for Oklahoma City's Capitol Hill High School| author=Tim Willert| date=February 26, 2015| publisher=News OK}}</ref> In a vote by students in May, 2015, Red Wolves was selected as the new mascot.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://newsok.com/red-wolves-will-replace-redskins-as-capitol-hill-high-school-mascot-in-oklahoma-city/article/5421767| title=Red Wolves will replace Redskins as Capitol Hill High School mascot in Oklahoma City| author=Tim Willert| date=May 23, 2015| publisher=The Oklahoman}}</ref>
The name of the [[Lancaster High School (Lancaster, New York)|Lancaster, New York High School]] team was discussed at a school board meeting in January, 2015. "Of all the words that could be used to describe us, 'Redskin' is the worst, said John Kane, talk show host for the First Voices Indigenous Radio Network". The school has de-emphasized the Redskins name in recent years, eliminating the name and logo from the scoreboard and uniforms. However, two former school board members defend the name, citing it as "a source of community identity, pride and spirit". Kane characterized the defense of the name as having an "[[Archie Bunker]]" mentality. "In this day and age, it's not a celebratory term," said Hilary N. Weaver, associate dean for academic affairs at the [[University at Buffalo]] and co-director of the Immigrant and Refugee Research Institute. "You're a school district, and it's important to look at what you're teaching. … I don't think racism has a place in an educational institution."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.buffalonews.com/city-region/lancaster/redskins-nickname-is-debated-in-lancaster-20150121| title=Redskins nickname is debated in Lancaster| author=Karen Robinson| date=January 21, 2015| newspaper=Buffalo News}}</ref> The name was again debated at the Lancaster school on March 3, 2015, and was defended by many, but not all current and former students. The President of the [[Seneca Nation of New York]], Maurice John Sr., wrote a letter stating: "Let's be clear — the term "redskin" is a racial slur ... I strongly disagree with those who argue that it is a term of honor and respect. It has no place in today's society." The letter was also addressed to President [[Barack Obama]], Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] and NFL Commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] with reference to the Washington NFL team.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://wivb.com/2015/03/03/lancaster-prepares-to-debate-redskin-name/| title=Lancaster debates the term Redskin| author=Brittni Smallwood| date=March 3, 2015| publisher=WIVB.com}}</ref> Two high schools, in [[Akron, New York|Akron]] and [[Lake Shore High School (New York)|Lake Shore]], have cancelled Lacrosse games with Lancaster in support of the Native American opposition to the Redskins name. The student population in the Lake Shore school district is 15% Native American, and 11% in Akron, while there are only a dozen Native Americans out of 6,000 students at Lancaster.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.buffalonews.com/city-region/schools/akron-and-lake-shore-cancel-lacrosse-games-with-lancaster-20150306| title=Akron and Lake Shore cancel lacrosse games with Lancaster| author=Jay Rey| date=March 6, 2015| newspaper=The Buffalo News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/10/sports/as-redskins-issue-splits-upstate-community-district-is-in-no-rush-to-decide.html?_r=1| title=As 'Redskins' Issue Splits Upstate Community, District Is in No Rush to Decide| author=Matt Higgins| date=March 10, 2015| newspaper=The New York Times}}</ref> On March 16, the Lancaster school board voted unanimously to retire the Redskin mascot.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Redskins Nickname Is Dropped by School District in Upstate New York |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/17/sports/upstate-school-district-drops-redskins-nickname.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |location=[[Lancaster, New York]] |date=16 March 2015 |access-date=17 March 2015}}</ref> Two days after the decision, about 300 students in favor of keeping the mascot protested, out of 2,000 total in the school district.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.newsday.com/news/region-state/redskins-nickname-being-dropped-by-lancaster-school-sparks-protest-1.10082694| title=Lancaster, NY students protest school's decision to drop Redskins nickname| date=March 19, 2015 |author=THE ASSOCIATED PRESS| publisher=Newsday}}</ref> The Lancaster School Board has been given a service award by the Western New York Educational Service Council for the courage and wisdom it displayed in determining that the current mascot was harmful to the Native American population.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.buffalonews.com/city-region/lancaster/lancaster-school-board-to-be-honored-for-mascot-name-change-20150331| title=Lancaster School Board to be honored for mascot name change| date=March 31, 2015| newspaper=The Buffalo News}}</ref> In June, 2015 a student vote selected ''Legends'' as the new name with a [[knight]] in armor as the new logo.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.wgrz.com/story/news/education/2015/06/03/new-lancaster-mascot-is/28420157/| title=New Lancaster Mascot is the Legends| date=June 3, 2015| publisher=WGRZ}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Redskins Mascot Overview|url=http://lancasterschools.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315051329/http://lancasterschools.org/Page/10643|archive-date=March 15, 2016|accessdate=1 October 2017}}</ref>
[[Fort Wayne, Indiana|Fort Wayne]] Community Schools officials began discussions in July 2015 to change the Redskins name used by [[North Side High School (Fort Wayne, Indiana)|North Side High School]] for its athletic teams, marching band and school nickname.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20150723/NEWS/150729850| title=FWCS discussing change of North Side H.S. Redskins nickname| author=Kevin Kilbane| publisher=The News-Sentinel| date=July 23, 2015| access-date=2018-11-22| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725094828/http://www.news-sentinel.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20150723%2FNEWS%2F150729850#| archive-date=2015-07-25| dead-url=yes| df=}}</ref> The nickname was changed to Legends in December, 2015.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.news-sentinel.com/opinion/Ready-to-root-for-the-North-Side-Legends-| title=Ready to root for the North Side Legends? 'Redskins' had just taken on too much baggage.| date=December 22, 2015| newspaper=News-Sentinel| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151223190844/http://www.news-sentinel.com/opinion/Ready-to-root-for-the-North-Side-Legends-| archivedate=December 23, 2015| df=}}</ref>
In [[Goshen, Indiana]] the majority of the school board was in favor of changing the mascot of [[Goshen High School (Indiana)|Goshen High School]]<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.goshennews.com/news/local_news/goshen-mascot-s-fate-may-come-by-end-of-month/article_b77831f6-29d3-11e5-9919-b73348d6cfc6.html| title=Goshen mascot's fate may come by end of month| author=Julie Crothers Beer| date=July 13, 2015| newspaper=Goshen News}}</ref> while others, including athletic staff favor maintaining what they view as part of a tradition of leadership and sportsmanship.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://athletics.goshenschools.org/goshen-redskins-mascot-statement/| title=Goshen Redskins Mascot Statement| author=Larry J. Kissinger, CAA, Director of Athletics, Goshen High School| accessdate=July 14, 2015}}</ref> The board decided in a 5-2 vote to retire the name, proponents citing the reevaluation spurred by the Washington NFL controversy. The [[Pokagon Band of Potawatomi Indians]] is among those advocating the change, saying in a written statement, "The R-word crosses a line for us. It's offensive, derogatory, and demeaning. ... Using the R-word perpetuates harmful stereotypes of Native Americans, and continues the damaging practice of relegating Native Americans to the past and portraying us as a caricature." The Goshen school board voted November 16, 2015 to adopt RedHawks as the new mascot, effective January 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.southbendtribune.com/news/education/redskins-mascot-no-more-in-goshen/article_785799be-3f7c-5cbc-81ec-dcd002a840d6.html| title= Redskins mascot no more in Goshen| author=Jacob Zinkula | publisher=South Bend Tribune| date=July 28, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.journalgazette.net/sports/high-schools/goshen-board-approves-redhawks-mascot-9962707| date=November 17, 2015| title=Goshen board approves RedHawks mascot| author=Associated Press}}</ref>
The [[Conrad Schools of Science]] in [[Wilmington, Delaware]] formed a "Retire the Mascot" committee to begin the process of changing the mascot that has been used for 80 years, but which many students and staff now agree is offensive to Native Americans.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/sports/high-school/2015/03/19/conrad-taking-steps-drop-redskins-name-mascot/25019071/| title=Conrad considers dropping Redskins nickname| author=Brad Myers| date=March 20, 2015| publisher=Delaware Online: The News Journal}}</ref> However, the president of the alumni association states that "He and other Conrad alumni wear their Redskins pins and clothing with pride."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://6abc.com/education/long-standing-mascot-at-wilmington-school-sparks-controversy/662444/| title=Long-standing mascot at Wilmington school sparks controversy| author= Monica Malpass| date=April 15, 2015| publisher=ABC Inc., WPVI-TV Philadelphia}}</ref> In May, 2016, the committee voted 9 to 4 to recommend that the [[Red Clay Consolidated School District]] that the name be changed. The chiefs of two local tribes, the [[Nanticoke tribe|Nanticoke]] and the [[Lenape]] are in favor of the change, but many alumni appeared at the meeting to oppose it.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/education/2016/05/02/redskins-mascot-up-debate-red-clay/83831920/| title=Conrad Schools of Science closer to losing Redskins name| author=Saranac Hale Spencer| publisher=Delaware Online: The News Journal| date=May 2, 2016}}</ref> In June, 2016, the Red Clay board voted 4-2 to drop the name, and begin the process of selecting another.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/education/2016/06/15/conrad-sheds-redskins-name/85952302/| title=Conrad Schools of Science sheds Redskins name| author=Saranac Hale Spencer| date=June 16, 2016}}</ref> The "Red Wolves" was selected by a student vote in February, 2017.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/education/2017/02/08/conrad-redskins-now-red-wolves/97645948/| title=Conrad Redskins now the Red Wolves| author=Jessica Bies| publisher=The News Journal Published| date=February 8, 2017}}</ref>
Citing the trend towards elimination of the Redskins mascot by other schools, Belding High School in [[Belding, Michigan|Michigan]] began tending towards the use of an Old English "B" logo in September 2016.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://wyrk.com/belding-michigan-is-having-the-same-redskins-debate-as-lancaster-ny-did/| title=Belding, Michigan Is Having the Same 'Redskins' Debate as Lancaster, NY Did| author=Rob Banks| date=September 20, 2016| publisher=WYRK-TV}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://thedailynews.cc/2016/10/13/beldings-mascot-debate-continues/| title='It's time for a change': Belding's mascot debate continues| author=Emilee Nielsen| date=October 13, 2016| publisher=The Daily News| access-date=2016-10-15| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016174357/http://thedailynews.cc/2016/10/13/beldings-mascot-debate-continues/#| archive-date=2016-10-16| dead-url=yes| df=}}</ref> The Belding Area Schools Board of Education unanimously voted December 19, 2016 to drop the Redskins and begin the process of selecting a new name.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://fox17online.com/2016/12/19/belding-school-board-unanimously-votes-to-remove-redskins-mascot/| title=Belding school board unanimously votes to remove 'Redskins' mascot| date=December 19, 2016| author=Cassy Arsenault| publisher=WXMI-TV}}</ref>
====California law==== Upon introducing a bill<ref>{{cite web| url=http://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201520160AB30| title=AB-30 School or athletic team names: California Racial Mascots Act. | accessdate=September 9, 2015}}</ref> to ban, as of January 2017, the Redskins name used by high schools in the state of [[California]], Assemblyman [[Luis Alejo]] stated that there is ""no reason why we can't ... phase out that particular derogatory term from our public high schools".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.mercurynews.com/high-school-sports/ci_27060195/assemblyman-seeks-ban-offensive-mascots-california-public-schools| title=Assemblyman seeks ban on offensive mascots in California public schools| author=Jason Hoppin| publisher=San Jose Mercury News| date=December 4, 2014}}</ref> The four affected high schools are [[Tulare Union High School]], [[Gustine High School]], [[Calaveras Unified School District|Calaveras High School]], and [[Chowchilla, California#Education|Chowchilla Union High School]].<ref name="Jessica Glenza">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/may/05/california-assembly-redskins-team-mascot-name| title=California assembly passes bill to ban 'Redskins' as high school team name | author=Jessica Glenza| publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> The governor signed the bill into law on October 11, 2015.<ref name="Melanie Mason"/>
Gustine High became the first to implement a change in February, 2016; becoming the "Reds", the name used by the school from 1913 to 1936.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.mercedsunstar.com/news/article59921746.html| title=Gustine chooses new mascot after governor bans Redskins | author=Brianna Calix| date=February 11, 2016| publisher=Merced Sun-Star}}</ref> After a vote between four alternatives, Calaveras High School has selected to remove the Redskins name, but not replace it. The logo featuring a Native American will be retained.<ref>{{cite news| title=Calaveras High School replaces Redskins with "no mascot"| author=Mike Taylor| date=May 26, 2016| publisher=Calaveras Enterprise}}</ref> Calaveras is calling itself "the Mighty Reds" on its web site while retaining its prior logo.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://chs.custudents.net/information/Sports| title=Calaveras High School sports| accessdate=January 23, 2017}}</ref> The Tulare school board began the process by surveying the public. The local Tule River Indian tribe is also being consulted.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.visaliatimesdelta.com/story/news/local/tulare/2016/02/10/tulare-union-announces-time-line-mascot-name-change/80215792/| title=Tulare community reacts to decision to drop Redskin mascot| author1=Luis Hernandez| author2=Calley Cedelof| publisher=Visalia Times-Delta| date=February 10, 2016}}</ref> The committee selected "The Tribe" as its top choice in April, 2016. The school principal stated their intention to retain Native American imagery as much as possible.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/education/article73274627.html| title=Tulare Union High trustees mull mascot options | author=Lewis Griswold| date=April 21, 2016| publisher=The Fresno Bee}}</ref> The Tulare Joint Union High School District board of trustees voted 3-2 for "Tribe" as the new mascot in June, 2016.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://abc30.com/education/the-tribe-tulare-union-gets-new-mascot-after-state-law-bans-redskins-name/1399523/http%3A%2F%2Fabc30.com%2F1399523%2F| title=The Tribe: Tulare Union gets new mascot after state law bans Redskins name| author=Christina Fan| date=June 23, 2016| publisher=KFSN-TV Fresno}}</ref> Chowchilla Union High School put off its decision until November 2016, after the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the school in October.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://abc30.com/society/chowchilla-high-holds-onto-redskins-name-for-now/1496572/| title=Chowchilla High holds onto Redskins name for now| date=September 2, 2016| publisher=KFSN TV - Fresno| author=Cory James}}</ref> The Chowchilla team name will be "Tribe", retaining their logo and Native American imagery.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.mercedsunstar.com/news/article113425303.html| title=Chowchilla High changes Redskins mascot to Tribe | date=November 8, 2016| publisher=Merced Sun-Star}}</ref>
As of the January 2017 deadline, three of the four schools have complied with the letter of the law but not the spirit, retaining their Native American imagery and behavior, including a female student portraying an Indian Pricess in a floor length war bonnet and fans whopping and tomahawk chopping at games. With the agreement of the local government, Chowchilla has added "Redskins Way" signs to the streets leading to the school and insist they are maintaining a proud tradition that honors Native Americans, even as tribal members state that these practices trivialize and misrepresent the factual history of Native Americans in California.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://edsource.org/2017/mascot-law-rolls-out-and-schools-obey-the-letter-of-the-law-if-not-the-spirit/575473| title=Mascot law rolls out and schools obey the letter of the law, if not the spirit| date=January 23, 2017| author=Jane Meredith Adams| publisher=EdSource}}</ref> {{further|Native American mascot laws and regulations}}
==Opposition to change== ===Neshaminy, Pennsylvania=== In 2013, after failing in her appeals directly to [[Neshaminy High School]], a parent, Donna Fann-Boyle (Cherokee-Choctaw) filed a complaint with the [[Pennsylvania]] Human Relations Commission (PHRC) alleging the "Redskins" name is a form of harassment offensive to Native Americans and her then 13-year-old son who attended the school. The school board unanimously voted to ask the commission to dismiss the complaint,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxphilly.com/story/23785675/parent-asks-school-to-change-mascot-name|title=Parent Asks School To Change Mascot Name|date=October 25, 2013|author=Omari Fleming|publisher=Fox News}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
As of November, 2014 the Neshaminy School District has incurred $26,000 in legal fees defending the mascot.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.buckscountycouriertimes.com/news/communities/hamptons/neshaminy-incurred-k-in-attorney-fees-over-mascot-name-issues/article_81d239b4-2e5a-5718-bda9-09231b56877d.html| title=Neshaminy incurred $26K in attorney fees over mascot name issues| author=Michael Macagnone| publisher=Bucks County Courier Times| date=December 21, 2014}}</ref> The PHRC has made a preliminary finding that the name Redskins is "racially derogatory" and creates a "hostile educational environment." The case will now proceed to a hearing by the full commission unless the school district takes steps to remedy the situation, which thus far they have refused to do.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.buckslocalnews.com/articles/2015/05/04/the_advance/news/doc553fbe5358ac2774244653.txt?viewmode=fullstory| title=State civil rights agency finds Neshaminy's use of 'Redskins' name 'racially derogatory,' could open door for lengthy proceedings| date=May 4, 2015| author=D.E. Schlatter| publisher=BucksLocalNews}}</ref> A hearing by the PHRC is expected in 2018, although the commission does not comment on cases in litigation.<ref name="Sinn.20171219">{{cite news| first=Dylan| last=Sinn| title=School paper becomes flashpoint in debate over 'Redskins'| agency=Capitol News Service| publisher=[[Philip Merrill College of Journalism]]| date=December 19, 2017| url=http://cnsmaryland.org/2017/12/19/school-paper-becomes-flashpoint-in-debate-over-redskins/ | accessdate=December 20, 2017}}</ref>
====School newspaper==== After hearing Fann-Boyle's and other Native Americans, editors of the student newspaper, the [[Neshaminy High School#Playwickian|Playwickian]], voted 14-7 to stop using the name.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.mcall.com/2013-10-25/news/mc-pa-neshaminy-school-redskin-controversy-20131025_1_student-newspaper-native-americans-editorial|title=Student newspaper to stop using school's 'Redskin' nickname|date=October 25, 2013|author=Christian Menno|newspaper=The Morning Call}}</ref> An editorial by the majority stated "The word 'Redskin' is racist, and very much so. It is not a term of honor, but a term of hate" and quoted Chief Bob Red Hawk member of the Lenape Nation as saying "Our children look at us when they hear this term with questions on why people would use this hateful word".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://playwickian.com/2918/op-ed/unsigned-editorial-why-we-wont-publish-the-r-word/| title=Unsigned Editorial: Why we won't publish the R-Word| date=October 23, 2013| accessdate=December 21, 2017| publisher=The Playwikian}}</ref> An editorial by the minority cited the schools traditions, their intent to honor Native Americans, and public opinion polls in support of keeping and printing the name.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://playwickian.com/2918/op-ed/unsigned-editorial-why-we-wont-publish-the-r-word/| title=Unsigned Editorial: School mascot: point of pride for high school| date=October 23, 2013| accessdate=December 21, 2017| publisher=The Playwikian}}</ref>
The principal and the school board president decided that the student newspaper's editorial board did not have the right to refuse to use the name.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/11/15/neshaminy-high-school-152276|title=Neshaminy High School's Editorial Board Challenged on Nixing 'Redskins'|date=November 15, 2013}}</ref> The school board reached a compromise policy in which the name would not be entirely banned, but allowed in editorials and letters to the editor; however the editors of the paper and their attorney maintain that this policy is contrary to state law and the [[United States Constitution|US Constitution]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.buckscountycouriertimes.com/news/local/neshaminy-board-passes-controversial-playwickian-policy/article_0f94aa14-3749-586c-930a-7d2e8c91ff78.html|title=Neshaminy board passes controversial Playwickian policy|date=June 26, 2014|author=MICHAEL MACAGNONE|newspaper=The Bucks County Courier Times}}</ref>
The Playwickian refusal to print the name came to a head when a student in favor of remaining Redskins submitted an editorial, which the paper printed with the name redacted. The principal eventually suspended the paper's faculty adviser, Tara Huber, for two days, and suspended editor-in-chief from her duties. The paper's funding was also cut by the approximate cost of the redacted issue.<ref name="Sinn.20171219"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.splc.org/article/2014/09/playwickian-adviser-student-editor-suspended-for-redskins-ban|title=Playwickian adviser, student editor suspended for defying administrative orders with Redskins ban|author=Anna Schiffbauer|date=September 17, 2014|publisher=Student Press Law Center}}</ref> The faculty adviser, Tara Huber was named Journalism Teacher of the Year in 2014 by the Pennsylvania School Press Association. The Playwickian journalists were honored by the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]] on October 8, 2014, receiving one of four Civil Libertarian Awards,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/local/20140910_Neshaminy_journalists_to_be_honored_by_ACLU.html|title=Neshaminy journalists to be honored by ACLU|date=September 10, 2014|publisher=Philly.com| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910193056/http://www.philly.com/philly/news/local/20140910_Neshaminy_journalists_to_be_honored_by_ACLU.html| archive-date=September 10, 2014| accessdate=May 31, 2018}}</ref> and in December, 2014 by the [[Philadelphia City Council]] with a resolution commending their actions.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://philadelphia.cbslocal.com/2014/12/04/philadelphia-city-council-honors-neshaminy-students-for-controversial-stand-on-racial-epithet/| title=Phila. City Council Honors Neshaminy Students For Controversial Stand on Racial Epithet| date=December 4, 2014| author=Mike Dunn| publisher=CBS Philly}}</ref> The editors of the school newspaper continue to oppose the use of the name, but have been reprimanded for doing so by the school administration.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.buckscountycouriertimes.com/news/local/neshaminy-principal-blocks-student-editor-access-to-playwickian-website/article_beabf27e-185b-11e6-9ba3-f7b422ae87b8.html| title=Neshaminy principal blocks student editor access to Playwickian website| date=May 13, 2016| publisher=Bucks County Courier-Times| author=Joan Hellyer}}</ref>
The law firm representing the [[Student Press Law Center]] has sent a [https://s3.amazonaws.com/media.spl/1307_letter_to_torrente_00953941xb68bao.pdf letter] to the solicitor of the Neshaminy School District citing the federal and state laws and school policy that have been violated by the school administration in failing to respect the independence decision of the Playwickian editorial board to redact the Redskins name in all articles submitted.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.splc.org/article/2016/06/neshaminy-high-school-revokes-student-newspaper-editors-access-to-post-and-edit-online| title=Neshaminy High School revokes student newspaper editor's access to post and edit online stories| author=Jordan Gass-Poore| date=June 13, 2016}}</ref>
===Other schools with controversies=== A May, 2018 school board meeting to discuss the team name of [[Anderson High School (Ohio)|Anderson High School]] in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]] ended in a shouting match between opponents and advocates of change, the latter including the Greater Cincinnati Native American Coalition.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/ap/ap_region/meeting-over-high-school-mascot-ends-in-shouting-match/article_25fde9f9-c454-5918-920a-82ad27d3dcd0.html| title= Meeting over high school mascot ends in shouting match| date=May 1, 2018| accessdate=May 3, 2018| author=Associated Press| publisher=The Herald-Dispatch}}</ref>
[[Union Public Schools|Union High School]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], a high-profile high school athletic program,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/sports/article.aspx?subjectid=227&articleid=20090706_298_0_Unionf830726| title=Sports Illustrated names Tulsa's Union on list of top athletic programs| newspaper=[[Tulsa World]]| date=July 6, 2009}}</ref> has consistently opposed protests and proposed legislation intended to change its "Redskins" nickname.<ref>{{cite news| author=Randy Krehbiel| url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/sportsextra/union-redskins-have-no-plans-to-change-name/article_62594bd2-64cc-5ed9-828a-e9d5faa8c18b.html| title=Union Redskins have no plans to change name| newspaper=[[Tulsa World]]| date=October 19, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| last = Kukla| first = Dan| title = Tulare Union High School stands by Redskin mascot amid national firestorm| work = Visalia Times-Delta and Tulare Advance-Register| accessdate = 2015-11-22| date = 2014-10-11| url = http://www.visaliatimesdelta.com/story/news/local/tulare/2014/10/11/pride-prejudice/17091537/}}</ref> However, a new mascot named "Hyper" has been introduced in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Winfrey| first = Katiera| title = Union Unveils New Mascot, Keeps Same Name| accessdate = 2015-09-15| url = http://www.newson6.com/story/30014216/union-unveils-new-mascot-keeps-same-name}}</ref>
The school board of McLoud Public Schools in Oklahoma met in December 2015, and after hearing testimony on both sides voted to keep the name.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://newsok.com/another-oklahoma-school-asked-to-change-teams-nickname/article/5465008| title=Another Oklahoma school asked to change teams' nickname| author=Andrew Knittle| date=December 6, 2015| publisher=The Oklahoman}}</ref>
In June 2013 the school superintendent in [[Driggs, Idaho]] announced that [[Teton High School]] would drop its longtime "Redskins" nickname, logo and mascot to show respect for Native Americans.<ref>{{Cite news| title = Idaho High School Drops Redskins Logo, Mascot| work = Huffington Post| accessdate = 2014-10-21| date = 2013-06-12| url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/12/teton-redskins-logo_n_3430496.html}}</ref> However, the decision was not immediately implemented due to the costs, and the school board has not taken any further action.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.tetonvalleynews.net/news/views-on-redskin-issue-largely-unchanged-since-last-year/article_6b705072-c02f-11e3-ab0b-0019bb2963f4.html| title=Views on Redskin issue largely unchanged since last year| date=April 11, 2014 |author=Scott Stuntz| publisher=Teton Valley News}}</ref>
The Canisteo-Greenwood School Board in [[New York (state)|New York]] also voted in 2013 to remove the mascot of their high school<ref>{{cite news| url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2013/06/13/uproar-canisteo-greenwood-school-board-meeting-over-redskins-mascot-149887| title= Another New York High School Will Drop Redskins Nickname and Mascot| date=June 6, 2013| publisher=Indian Country Today}}</ref> but reversed the decision due to public opposition.
The mascot of the [[Paw Paw Public Schools]], [[Paw Paw, Michigan]] had been the subject of discussion for more than 20 years. While votes to retain the name have been passed, protests continue making the issue recur.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.pawpawcourierleader.com/news/area_news/article_9fa203ae-2965-11e5-8247-e7abb5253ed7.html| title=Longtime school mascot under review at Paw Paw| date=July 13, 2015| author=Paul Garrod| newspaper=The Courier-Leader}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://fox17online.com/2016/09/10/rally-held-in-paw-paw-in-hopes-to-change-school-districts-mascot/| title=Group marches to change Paw Paw school's Redskins mascot| date=September 10, 2016| author=Alyssa Hearin| publisher=WXMI-TV}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.mlive.com/news/kalamazoo/index.ssf/2016/11/paw_paw_school_board_ponders_-.html| title=Paw Paw school board again ponders district's Redskins mascot| author=Rosemary Parker| date=November 10, 2016| publisher=MLive Media Group}}</ref> Change was narrowly defeated in a school board vote in 2017.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://woodtv.com/2017/02/08/paw-paw-redskins-mascot-decision/| title=Paw Paw schools will stay with Redskins mascot: Matter cannot be revisited unless government funding is at stake| author=Lynsey Mukomel| date=February 8, 2017| publisher=WOOD-TV}}</ref> In protest, a Native American rights group erected a billboard in 2018 near I-94 in Paw Paw pointing to the dictionary definition of the term as disparaging and offensive.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://fox17online.com/2018/08/15/billboard-protesting-use-of-redskins-as-mascot-posted-near-paw-paw/| title=Billboard protesting use of ‘Redskins’ as mascot posted near Paw Paw| date=August 15, 2018| publisher=Fox 17| accessdate=August 15, 2018 }}</ref>
Although two former students who are Native American began a protest to change the mascot of [[Clinton Community Schools]] in [[Clinton, Lenawee County, Michigan|Michigan]], community support at a special meeting to discuss the issue resulted in a decision to keep the name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toledonewsnow.com/story/12402134/controversial-clinton-schools-redskins-mascot-will-stay|title=Controversial Clinton School's Redskins mascot will stay|date=April 29, 2010|author=Colleen Wells|publisher=Toledo News Now|accessdate=2013-11-15}}</ref>
The leader of the local Native American group views the name Redskins as having a hurtful history, he does not seek to change the mascot of [[Hurricane High School (West Virginia)|Hurricane High School]] in [[Hurricane, West Virginia|West Virginia]], but educate non-natives about Native American culture.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.wowktv.com/story/25791219/high-school-mascot-controversy| title=High School mascot controversy looms in Hurricane, WV| date=June 16, 2014| author=Hillary Hall| publisher=WOWK-TV}}</ref>
While aware of the controversy over the Washington team, there is no local discussion regarding [[Loudon High School]] in [[Loudon, Tennessee|Tennessee]] changing its name.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wbir.com/story/news/local/lenoir-city-loudon/2013/10/18/redskins-name-at-loudon-hs-a-tradition-despite-national-controversy/3013963/|title=Redskins name at Loudon H.S. a tradition, despite national controversy|author=Stephen W Butera|publisher=WBIR|date=October 18, 2013}}</ref>
==Other teams== Throughout the country, some of the other teams with the Redskins name must deal with the controversy.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2014/10/02/washington-redskins-nickname-change| title=Youth leagues also wrestling with controversial Redskins nickname| author=Sarah Barshop| publisher=Sports Illustrated| date=October 2, 2014}}</ref> Others say there have been no complaints, including a youth league in Sarasota, Florida, the "Ringling Redskins" in which the teams are the "Braves", "Indians", and "Warriors".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.mysuncoast.com/news/local/local-redskins-youth-league-not-feeling-pressure-to-change-name/article_99d81a1a-f7f9-11e3-abc4-001a4bcf6878.html| title=Local Redskins youth league not feeling pressure to change name| date=June 19, 2014|publisher=WWSB ABC 7}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://leaguelineup.com/welcome.asp?sid=588888378&url=redskins| title=Satasota Ringling Redskins| accessdate=November 18, 2015| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119191248/http://leaguelineup.com/welcome.asp?sid=588888378&url=redskins#| archive-date=2015-11-19| dead-url=yes| df=}}</ref>
===Baseball=== * Midland Redskins, [[Batavia, Ohio]]<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.midlandredskins.com| title=Midland Redskins}}</ref>
===Hockey=== * Morden Redskins, South Eastern Manitoba Hockey League<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/pages/Morden-Redskins/210055252400760 Morden Redskins]</ref>

Florida|url=http://www.antiochredskins.org/|access-date=2015-10-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151013204727/http://antiochredskins.org/#|archive-date=2015-10-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *Dearborn Heights Redskins Jr. Football, Dearborn Heights, MI<ref>[http://www.ci.dearborn-heights.mi.us/AffiliatedYouthSports.cfm Dearborn Heights Redskins Jr. Football]</ref> *Donaldsonville Redskins, [[Donaldsonville, Louisiana]] <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donaldsonvillechief.com/article/20121115/Sports/121119927|title=D'ville Redskins headed to the Superbowl|author=DeRon Talley|date=November 15, 2012|newspaper=The Donaldsonville Chief}}</ref> *Fauquier Youth Football, [[Fauquier County, Virginia]] Grayling, MI<ref>[http://www.i2k.com/~samleague/redskins.html Grayling Redskins Youth Football]</ref> *Jackson Redskins Sports Club, [[Jackson, Mississippi]]
