|url=http://www.jrredskins.com/# |title=Lancaster Junior Redskins |access-date=2018-11-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927141340/http://www.jrredskins.com/# |archive-date=2017-09-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *Loudon Redskins Youth Football, [[Loudon, Tennessee]] <ref>[https://www.facebook.com/pages/Loudon-Quarterback-Club/400156526716578 Loudon Redskins Youth Football, Loudon, Tennessee]</ref> *New Rock Redskins, Conyers, GA (Ages 6–12) Uses the DC team logo<ref>[http://www.newrockredskins.org/ New Rock Redskins]</ref> *Ohio Redskins Youth Sports Association, [[Columbus, Ohio]] <ref>[https://www.facebook.com/midwestredskins/info Ohio Redskins Youth Sports Association]</ref> *Rochester Redskins, [[Rochester, Michigan]] <ref>[http://www.rochesterredskins.com/ Rochester Redskins, Rochester, Michigan Rochester Redskins]</ref> *Patterson Redskins Football (youth) Patterson, CA<ref>[http://www.pattersonredskins.com/ Patterson Redskins Football] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141218004507/http://pattersonredskins.com/ |date=2014-12-18 }}</ref> *Sarasota Redskins, [[Sarasota, Florida]] <ref>[http://www.sarasotaredskinsyouthfootball.com/ Sarasota Redskins]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mysuncoast.com/news/local/local-redskins-youth-league-not-feeling-pressure-to-change-name/article_99d81a1a-f7f9-11e3-abc4-001a4bcf6878.html|title=Local Redskins youth league not feeling pressure to change name|date=June 19, 2014|publisher=WWSB}}</ref> *South Cherokee Redskins Association, [[Woodstock, Georgia]] <ref>[http://www.nwgyfl.org/page/show/878235-south-cherokee-redskins South Cherokee Redskins]</ref><ref>[http://www.scraredskins.com/default.aspx South Cherokee Redskins Association, Woodstock, Georgia South Cherokee Redskins Association]</ref> *Southwest Redskins, [[Houston, Texas]] <ref>[http://southwestredskins.com/ Southwest Redskins, Houston, Texas Southwest Redskins]</ref> *Sterling Heights Redskins, Sterling Heights, MI (youth) Uses the DC team logo<ref>[http://www.sterlingheightsredskins.com/ Sterling Heights Redskins]</ref> *Stonybrook Redskins, Indianapolis, IN *Washington Redskins Midget Football, [[Washington, New Jersey]]<ref>[http://wrafootball.homestead.com/ Washington Redskins Midget Football, Washington, New Jersey]</ref> *Wayland Redskins, Wayland, NY (Youth Football ages 6–12)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://waylandredskins.com/# |title=Wayland Redskins |access-date=2015-10-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108131110/http://waylandredskins.com/# |archive-date=2014-01-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> *Whittier Redskins, [[Whittier, California]] *Woonsocket Redskins, Woonsocket, RI – Youth Football (K-9th grade) Uses the DC team logo<ref>[http://www.eteamz.com/WOONSOCKETREDSKINS Woonsocket Redskins]</ref>
===Wrestling=== * Morris, IL – Little Redskins IKWF sanctioned wrestling club (K-8th grade) Uses a version of the DC team logo<ref>[http://www.littleredskins.com/ns/ Little Redskins] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150812234832/http://www.littleredskins.com/ns/ |date=2015-08-12 }}</ref>
===Teams outside the Americas=== Native American names and images are used by teams in other countries, generally those playing American-style sports and copying the imagery of American teams. Several are in Austria and Germany, which have a tradition of [[Native American hobbyism in Germany|Native American hobbyists]]. The controversy is also international, with the ice hockey team in [[Streatham]], England dropping its Redskins nickname in 2016 to become the [[Streatham Redhawks]].
* Bürstadt Redskins, an American Football club in [[Bürstadt]], [[Germany]]<ref>{{cite web| title=Bürstadt Redskins| url=http://www.redskinsfootball.de/| accessdate=7 September 2017}}</ref> * [[Dornbirn]] Indians, Redskins, and "Little Indians", a [[:de:Austrian Baseball League|youth baseball club]] in [[Austria]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.indians.at/newHomepage/#| title=Dornbirn Indians| accessdate=December 16, 2016| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170510190041/http://www.indians.at/newHomepage/| archivedate=May 10, 2017| df=}}</ref> * Raynes Park Little League, [[Kensington]], [[England]] - Redskins<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.raynesparklittleleague.com/?p=203 |title=RPLL: Redskins |accessdate=25 June 2016}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = The Lamb Ground | nickname = | image = [[Image:The Lamb Ground.jpg|200px]] | location = Kettlebrook Road
[[Tamworth, Staffordshire|Tamworth]]
[[Staffordshire]]
B77 1AA | opened = 1934 | owner = [[Tamworth F.C.]] | operator = [[Tamworth F.C.]] | surface = 3G | construction_cost = | capacity = 4,000 | architect = | tenants = [[Tamworth F.C.]] (1934–present) | seating_capacity = 4,065 (518 seated) }} '''The Lamb Ground''' is a football stadium in the district of Kettlebrook, in [[Tamworth, Staffordshire|Tamworth]], [[Staffordshire]], [[England]] and the home of [[Tamworth F.C.]] It is approximately half a mile south of [[Tamworth railway station]]. ==History== [[Tamworth F.C.|Tamworth]] spent their first year as a football team at Jolly Sailor ground before making the short move across the [[River Tame, West Midlands|River Tame]] to start the 1934/35 season in the [[Birmingham Combination]] at the Lamb Ground. [[Tamworth F.C.|Tamworth]] have continued to play at the same site ever since, steadily improving the facilities as the Lambs progressed up the non-league football pyramid. The ground was named after the "Lamb Inn", which stood for many years at the entrance to what is now the ground's car park. The first known use of the site was as a pig farm at the turn of the 19th century. Before [[Tamworth F.C.|Tamworth]] arrived at the Lamb Ground it is believed that Kettlebrook Oakfield F.C. used the ground. In those early days, players had to change in the Lamb Inn and run down to the pitch, but facilities have been slowly built up to include changing rooms and a clubhouse, as well as 'cover' and seating for spectators. In 1969 the Lamb Ground acquired its floodlights from [[Scarborough F.C.|Scarborough]] and all bar one of the original pylons are still in place to date, one having been removed to make way for the construction of the current Main Stand in 1997. [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] were invited to play a friendly fixture to mark the official switch-on of the floodlights owing to the Gills being Tamworth's first Football League opposition in the [[FA Cup]]. The Main Stand holds 518 while the terraced "Shed" is home to the "Shed Choir" which sometimes provide the team with vocal support. Planning permission has been sought for a new 1,800 seater stand incorporating VIP boxes to take the place of the current Main Stand, its thought the current Main Stand would then be moved to the Castle End of the stadium. However this may have been a smoke screen whilst the team were seriously under performing to try and prevent fans unease at the situation. ==External links== *[http://www.thelambs.co.uk/page/index.asp?pageCatID=4&pageID=38 Club Information - the Lamb Ground] {{Tamworth F.C.}} {{Conference National Venues}} {{coord|52|37|42.25|N|1|41|20.13|W|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lamb Ground,The}} [[Category:Tamworth F.C.]] [[Category:Aston Villa L.F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues in Staffordshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1934]] [[Category:Sport in Tamworth, Staffordshire]] {{England-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox television | show_name = The Timeline | image = | creator = [[NFL Films]]
[[NFL Network]] | genre = Documentary | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 3 | network = [[NFL Network]] | first_aired = {{start date|2015|12|03}} | last_aired = {{end date|Present}} | num_episodes = 21 }} '''''The Timeline''''' is a documentary series developed by [[NFL Films]] and airs on [[NFL Network]] that documents select events of the [[National Football League]].http://www.nfl.com/network/shows/the-timeline ==Episodes== ===Season One=== {| class=wikitable |- !No. !Title !Event(s) !Narrator !Original air date |- |1 |Favre Returns |[[Brett Favre]] retiring as a [[Green Bay Packers|Green Bay Packer]] in March 2008, only to un-retire a few months later to join the [[New York Jets]], and then join the Packers' rival, the [[Minnesota Vikings]], in 2009. |[[Tim McGraw]] |December 3, 2015http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000593747/article/brett-favre-is-a-man-at-peace-in-timeline-premiere |- |2 |Jersey Guys |The [[New York Giants]], after suffering losing seasons in the 1960s and early 1970s, move from [[New York City]] to [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] in 1976 and become a winning team in the 1980s. |[[Bon Jovi]] |December 8, 2015http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000597507/article/jersey-guys-examines-giants-garden-state-romance |- |3 |A Tale of Two Cities: Part 1 |The [[49ers–Cowboys rivalry]] during the 1970s and 1980s, and the impact the two teams had on their respective cities. |[[Sam Elliott]] & [[Jeremy Renner]] |December 15, 2015http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000603073/article/a-tale-of-two-cities-shines-light-on-an-alltime-rivalry |- |4 |A Tale of Two Cities: Part 2 |The 49ers–Cowboys rivalry during the 1990s, when San Francisco and Dallas faced each other in the [[NFC Championship Game]] three consecutive times. |[[Sam Elliott]] & [[Jeremy Renner]] |December 19, 2015http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000603073/article/a-tale-of-two-cities-shines-light-on-an-alltime-rivalry |- |5 |The Merger |The war between the NFL and the [[American Football League]], and the subsequent [[AFL–NFL merger|merger]] between the two rival leagues in 1970. |[[Rich Eisen]] & [[James Brown (sportscaster)|James Brown]] |December 24, 2015http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000607853/article/the-merger-looks-at-time-of-vital-change-in-football |- |6 |America's Game and the Iran Hostage Crisis |The NFL during the [[Iran hostage crisis]]. Includes the story of Alex Paen, a Los Angeles-based reporter stationed in Tehran, who made an audio recording of [[Super Bowl XIV]] for the hostages to listen to. |[[George Clooney]] |December 26, 2015https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/dc-sports-bog/wp/2015/12/23/nfl-network-documentary-tells-story-of-the-nfls-link-to-the-iran-hostage-crisis/ |} ===Season Twohttp://www.nfl.com/network/shows/the-timeline=== {| class=wikitable |- !No. !Title !Event(s) !Narrator !Original air date |- |1 |September 11th |The NFL during and after the [[September 11 attacks]]. |Mary McDonald-Lewis |September 9, 2016 |- |2 |Last Day in LA |The last regular season games of the [[Los Angeles Raiders]] and the [[Los Angeles Rams]] before they relocated to [[Oakland]] and [[St. Louis]], respectively, after the 1994 season. |[[William Fichtner]] |September 14, 2016 |- |3 |Rebirth in New Orleans |The [[New Orleans Saints]] and the city of [[New Orleans]], from the aftermath of [[Hurricane Katrina]] to the re-opening of the [[Louisiana Superdome]] more than a year later. |[[Clarke Peters]] |September 21, 2016 |- |4 |Night of the Living Steelers |The 1970s [[Pittsburgh Steelers]], as re-told by horror filmmaker and former Pittsburgh resident [[George A. Romero]]. |[[George A. Romero]] |October 5, 2016 |- |5 |Peyton Manning's Summer School |Quarterback [[Peyton Manning]]'s off-season workout routine, and how it prepared him and the [[2013 Denver Broncos season|2013 Denver 26 games. |''None'' |November 23, 2016 |- |7 |There's Only One America's Team |The [[Dallas Cowboys]] getting the nickname "[[America's Team]]". |[[Josh Holloway]] |November 30, 2016 |- |8 |1984 – The Season That Saved Football |The [[1984 NFL season]], which began at a time when the league was facing declining ratings, the lingering effects of the [[1982 NFL strike]], and the upstart [[United [[Mike Ditka]], and Eagles head coach and former Bears defensive coordinator [[Buddy Ryan]]. |[[John Cusack]] |December 21, 2016 |} ===Season Threehttp://www.nfl.com/network/shows/the-timeline=== {| Green Bay Packers|Green Bay Packers]]. Directed and narrated by filmmaker [[Michael Meredith]], son of Dallas quarterback [[Don Meredith]], who spent four years researching more about the game's significance 50 years after it was played. |[[Michael Meredith]] |December 29, 2017 |- |5 |The Helmet Catch |[[New York Giants]] wide receiver [[David Tyree]]'s "[[Helmet Catch]]" during the final minutes of [[Super Bowl XLII]], that helped his team win the game and prevent the New England Patriots from completing a perfect season. |[[Morgan Spector]] |February 2, 2018 |} ==References== {{reflist}} {{National Football League on television and radio}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Timeline, The}} [[Category:NFL Films]] [[Category:NFL Network shows]] [[Category:Documentaries about sports]] [[Category:2015 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2010s American television series]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=April 2017}}
[[File:Motherwell volley.jpg|thumb|180px| [[Motherwell F.C.|Motherwell]] player [[Brian McLean]] volleys the ball in a match against [[St Mirren F.C.|St Mirren]].]] A '''volley''' is an air-borne strike in [[association football]], where a player's foot meets and directs the ball in an angled direction before it has time to reach the ground. A volley can be extremely hard to aim and requires good foot-eye coordination and timing.
In general, the volley requires that the player strike the ball with the front of his foot, with the toes pointing downward, ankle locked, and the knee lifted. It is important for most applications to keep the knee high over the ball when struck, and lean slightly forward to keep the shot accurate and keeping it down. Doing so imparts a great deal of [[topspin]] and prevents the ball from flying wildly over the goal if done correctly. Because of the power and spin imparted on the ball, the shot can follow an unpredictable path to goal and prove difficult to defend against.
Used offensively, the volley can play a crucial role in scoring straight goals. Since a volley occurs when the ball is in the air, they often occur in front of goal as a result of a [[Cross (football)|cross]] or a [[Corner kick|corner]]. In this instance, one attacking player passes the ball across the goal in the air, and the other player (either standing in place or in motion) strikes the ball with his foot before it hits the ground. This is advantageous over a normal strike in that the player does not need to trap the ball, taking an extra touch and allowing the [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] a few extra seconds to react. Generally, the ball is struck on the laces with the toe pointing downward towards goal, though variations such as the [[bicycle kick]] or scissors kick in which the player's body moves in acrobatic fashion are occasionally employed, much to the delight of spectators.
Used defensively, the volley can quickly clear the ball from play and allow the defending team to recover their position. While less accurate and harder to execute than a normal long pass, the volley is useful for clearing balls that are bouncing towards or away from a defender because he does not need to trap the ball or change directions if he's running towards his own goal.
The volley is used less often for passes, as it is harder to control, though it can often be used to flick the ball on to another player. In this use, the strike is softer and more controlled than either the shot or the clearance. Also, the inside of the foot, outside, or even the heel may be used to flick the ball on off of a volley. When the heel is used to volley the ball over the player's head (from back to front) it is often referred to as a "donkey kick".
A Half Volley is also commonly used, which is when the ball is kicked immediately after it hits the ground. An exquisite example of a half volley is Liverpool FC's Terry McDermott's goal against Spurs at White Hart Lane in 1980. The ball came to Mc Dermott about 6 metres outside the left corner of Spurs' 18 yard box. Mc Dermott struck the ball that arched into the Spurs net leaving the keeper grasping thin air. However, probably the greatest example is that by Luis Suarez, again for Liverpool FC, against Norwich in an English Premier league fixture in 2013. The ball came to Suarez halfway inside the Norwich half approximately 40 metres from goal. Suarez's looping half volley shot gave the keeper no chance as it found the back of the net.
